HEADLINE: Spinning Frenzy: P.R.'s Bad Press

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN

 BODY:
FOR years, Armstrong Williams, co-founder of Graham Williams Group, a public relations agency in Washington, has catered to clients in politics, business and entertainment. His partner at the agency is Stedman Graham, the boyfriend of Oprah Winfrey. Mr. Williams is also a popular and ubiquitous political commentator, advocating individual accountability and ethical rectitude as a leading African-American conservative.
 One of the Web sites of this P.R.-specialist-cum-commentator captures the flavor of his professional portfolio: ''Williams has become a multimedia wonder, taking stands for what's right on radio and television, in print and in cyberspace. Focusing on issues such as the work ethic, personal responsibility and especially the restoration of morality in today's society, Williams brings an independent view with a refreshing twist to the central issues of our day.''
 But in early January, Mr. Williams's independence and ethical bearings came under scrutiny. He acknowledged that the Department of Education had paid him $240,000 to promote its ''No Child Left Behind'' initiative during radio and television appearances. Until USA Today reported the arrangement last month, anyone watching or listening to him discuss White House policy would probably have been under the impression that his opinions were unsponsored. 
 While Mr. Williams enjoys a free-floating job profile -- spin doctor, commentator, entrepreneur -- many public relations executives and industry critics say his activities fell outside the ethical fold. And the fact that a major public relations firm, Ketchum, helped to orchestrate the education department's stealthy sales pitch has prompted a heated debate within one of the country's most influential businesses.
 The controversy comes as other changes are roiling the information business. Public relations specialists are scrambling to adjust to a time in which the Internet revolution and a boom in alternative media sources are rewriting the parameters of the communications industry and challenging traditional sources of authority. So, despite an avalanche of freely available information, the truth is becoming harder to discern.
 ''P.R. has a P.R. problem,'' said Brenda J. Wrigley, an associate professor of public relations at Syracuse University. ''We have to get our own house in order before we go around advising corporations what to do. We are advocates and there's no shame in that as long as it's grounded in ethics and values.
 ''This has to be seen against a very partisan political background in which both parties are doing anything they can to get points of view across at a time when almost anyone can start blogging and call themselves a journalist,'' she added. ''I can't imagine Armstrong Williams will be the only story to emerge from all of this. I think there's got to be more.''
 MR. WILLIAMS'S fee was part of a $950,000 government contract that Ketchum signed last June. The agency, a division of the Omnicom Group, agreed to enlist Mr. Williams as an advocate and hired his firm to produce advertisements promoting the Bush administration's education policy. 
 Federal law prohibits covert government publicity or propaganda campaigns. And Congressional Democrats, spotting an excellent opportunity to generate buzz, have introduced legislation seeking to curtail government-financed publicity. The Department of Education and the General Accounting Office are investigating the Williams matter. 
 President Bush said in a recent news conference that he had been unaware of either the arrangement with Mr. Williams or the payments the government made to another commentator, Maggie Gallagher, to give advice on White House policies. The president ordered federal agencies not to replicate those arrangements and, shortly thereafter, the government disclosed that it had ended payments to a third commentator, Michael McManus, who had also advised the government. Omnicom and Ketchum, which the General Accounting Office criticized last year for producing fake news videos promoting the White House's prescription drug plan, did not respond to repeated requests for interviews.
 Mr. Williams, who began his career in public relations before emerging as a radio personality in the 1990's, declined to be interviewed for this article. He has told reporters that he regretted accepting the $240,000 payment, but he has refused to return his fee to the government, telling USA Today that to do so ''would be ludicrous because they bought advertising, and they got it.''
 Ketchum and three other public relations agencies owned by Omnicom appear to have delivered the bulk of the White House's messages. According to a study prepared by Congressional Democrats, those four agencies snared about $223 million of the $250 million that the federal government spent on public relations contracts from 2001 to 2004. 
 Five federal agencies accounted for the bulk of federal spending on public relations: the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, the National Institutes of Health, the Minerals Management Service, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the Health Resources and Services Administration. The report also noted a sharp increase in public relations contracts awarded by the government on a noncompetitive basis.
 The Bush White House is hardly the first to contract with such firms. The same Congressional study noted that from 1997 to 2000, during President Bill Clinton's second term, the government spent $128 million on public relations. At issue, however, is not the amount of money spent; it is the amount of spin deployed.
 ''The Armstrong Williams scandal is an example of the close coordination between the advertiser and the commentator,'' said Sheldon Rampton, research director at the Center for Media and Democracy, a left-leaning nonprofit group that tracks abuses in the public relations business. ''In terms of journalistic traditions, that violates disclosure and conflicts-of-interest principles.''
 Many public relations executives said that they aspired to be honest information brokers and that Ketchum's activities were atypical. They said that their government work often involved promotion of vital policy issues, and that passionate advocacy is fine as long as the sponsor of a message or product is not hidden from public view.
 ''At the end of the day, P.R. is about trying to communicate a message on someone's behalf,'' said Harris Diamond, chief executive of Weber Shandwick, one of the largest public relations firms in the country. ''It is very important that we have transparency in our practices. We have to give very clear guidance on where information is coming from.''
 What is clear, though, is that the number of large firms communicating those messages has been shrinking. Sweeping consolidation has transformed public relations over the last two decades, with such publicly traded global communications giants as Omnicom, the WPP Group, the Interpublic Group, and Publicis Groupe acquiring a bevy of large, formerly independent firms. These behemoths have picked off well-known companies like Ketchum, Fleishman-Hillard, Hill & Knowlton, Weber Shandwick and Burson-Marsteller, placing them inside holding companies that also operate advertising, strategic consulting and marketing businesses.
 Even before the consolidation began, public relations had grown from a business populated by stereotypical spinmeisters trying to chalk up glowing coverage for their clients into a more lucrative and sophisticated field inhabited by advisers who occupy a vaunted ''seat at the C.E.O.'s table.'' (Still, courting the news media remains the primary task of most smaller public relations firms). 
 Some firms' duties have evolved to encompass political lobbying, legal advice, pitches to the media and public relations campaigns that span continents. Burson-Marsteller and APCO Worldwide, for example, have served as particularly aggressive advocates for Russia's controversial business elites, while Qorvis Communications is one of the Saudi Arabian government's chief American advisers. 
 As a result of these changes, publicists are pulling in more money than ever. In 2002, the country's top 10 public relations firms billed clients about $2.5 billion, compared with top-10 billings of just $192 million in 1968, according to inflation-adjusted data compiled by the Council of Public Relations Firms, an industry trade group. Because communications conglomerates have stopped breaking out public relations billings, 2002 was the last year for which reliable industry-wide data is available.
 But reaching an audience has become much more challenging for public relations firms, just as it has for traditional news media. The Internet, declining newspaper readership and the growth of cable television and niche magazines have combined to splinter the news and television audience. Public relations has had to find new ways to connect with people, whether through much-maligned video news releases, event marketing or the use of third-party advocates like Mr. Williams. 
 Temptations to push the ethical envelope abound. ''We're going through a period of a huge jolt, and now more than ever we have to teach our account people a moral compass,'' said Richard W. Edelman, president of Edelman, the nation's largest independent public relations firm. ''Every piece of information we put out, in theory, can go directly to the end user without any mediation. But our job today is still to bring to the media a credible story.''
 Communications conglomerates, however, make much more money from advertising than from public relations. As a result, critics say, firms like Ketchum that operate inside conglomerates are pushing harder to fatten the bottom line -- which may lead them to cross ethical boundaries.
 Critics also say that the billions of dollars in debt the conglomerates have incurred during their acquisition spree has made them pursue fees more aggressively. ''It's our belief that the masters of the universe, if you will -- WPP and these other guys -- are pressing for higher profits,'' said Daniel J. Edelman, father of Richard and founder of the company that bears his name. ''They have standards for what they want, usually 17 percent margins. We like to do well, but we're not trying to hit those kinds of numbers. It takes away from our historic relationship with the media.''
 Executives at WPP, Publicis and Interpublic said that their public relations units operate with great latitude. They also contended that independent firms had a self-interested reason for promoting themselves as less profit-hungry than those inside conglomerates: it is good public relations. 
 The three companies also said that they emphasized ethics in their corporate cultures and denied that there was pressure exerted on their public relations units to hunt recklessly for large fees. ''I'd like to see some evidence of that,'' said Howard Paster, a WPP director. ''I don't think that's the case. I've heard that argument before and I think it's specious.''
 Mr. Paster said that it is ''axiomatic that you don't pay for coverage'' and that Ketchum and Mr. Williams's activities do not represent systemic problems within the public relations field.
 Howard Rubenstein, a veteran New York publicist, said his firm, has received buyout offers from conglomerates over the years but that he has demurred. Running an independent, private company, he said, gives him greater flexibility and freedom from short-term profit pressure. He said he thought the controversy surrounding Ketchum and Mr. Williams might have a salutary affect on the public relations field.
 ''The good part is that people who do unethical things will be exposed more quickly, and I think it will create a standard that did not exist in our industry for a long time,'' said Mr. Rubenstein, who entered the field in 1954. ''In my early years, if you couldn't get a column into Walter Winchell you were nobody. How things have changed. We're much more strategically important now.''
 PUBLIC relations as a formal endeavor first took shape early in the 20th century, when another seismic communications shift was under way: the rapid growth of the newspaper business, with New York as its epicenter. P.R. piggybacked on the news boom as well as on another newfangled entity: the corporation. John D. Rockefeller Sr., architect of both the modern corporation and the Standard Oil monopoly, retained the services of the father of public relations, Ivy Lee, after being blindsided by critical and sometimes inaccurate articles.
 According to ''Titan,'' the Rockefeller biography by Ron Chernow, Mr. Lee tried to repackage the industrialist as a humane philanthropist, and in so doing became an important counsel to John D. Rockefeller Jr. as well. Mr. Lee, whose career later foundered when it was revealed that he did promotional work for the Nazis, advised the Rockefellers to be frank and direct when discussing their business practices with the press -- a relief to a family averse to the practice, then common, of bribing reporters for coverage.
 In the 1920's, Edward Bernays, a relative of Sigmund Freud, led publicists into new waters by emphasizing psychological research and advocating the use of seemingly objective third-party authorities to sway public opinion. He professionalized the business while introducing other new forms of manipulation, like establishing bogus front groups to promote the benefits of smoking. 
 Arthur Page, an in-house public relations adviser to AT&T from the 1920's through the 1940's, embraced the concept of good corporate citizenship and pushed AT&T to be open and honest in its press dealings. The tension between proponents of Bernays-like manipulation and Page-style transparency has existed in the business ever since.
 Many involved in the government's psychological warfare and public information campaigns during World War II became part of a new crop of publicity agents in postwar America. Some of them established public relations agencies that blossomed in the 1960's, when the rise of television created another monumental communications dislocation and a publicity gold rush. Most of those firms are among those that conglomerates have acquired in the recent consolidation.
 PUBLIC relations scandals have cropped up periodically over the years. Hill & Knowlton, which WPP acquired in 1987, came under heavy criticism for the misleading video news releases it produced for the government of Kuwait in 1990. The videos, which included false reports of atrocities committed by Saddam Hussein, were intended to drum up public opposition in the United States to the Iraqi leader before the Persian Gulf War of 1991. Today, Fleishman-Hillard, an Omnicom company, is enmeshed in a scandal involving accusations by the Los Angeles city controller that the firm and a former executive overbilled the city for their services. 
 The former Fleishman executive is contesting the accusations. A Fleishman spokesman said that the incident was an aberration involving a small number of employees and that the firm maintained high ethical standards. 
 But others say the incident may echo of larger forces at work in the public relations industry.
 ''There's no question in my mind that the padding of bills has to do with firms chasing higher profits,'' Daniel J. Edelman said. ''I think bill-padding is a reflection of consolidation.''
 Yet it is Ketchum's imbroglio with Mr. Williams and the Education Department that seems to have struck a particularly indignant nerve among some longtime public relations analysts. ''This is the Three Mile Island of the P.R. business,'' said Jack O'Dwyer, a public relations gadfly in New York who heads a research firm and publishes a newsletter bearing his name. ''The industry began selling its soul when it sold out to these advertising companies because the public relations business should be about the truth, not about sales.''
 Senior executives at the conglomerates said they thought such criticism was alarmist and reiterated their view that consolidation had brought increased sophistication and more resources to public relations efforts, without a loss of integrity.
 According to 2002 data collected by the Council of Public Relations Firms, a trade group, only 9 percent of the industry's revenue came from work performed for governments and nonprofit groups. The remainder derived from corporate advocacy.
 BUT it is government contracts that have raised the current specter of the industry's involvement with covert propagandizing. Public relations executives say that much of their government work is bipartisan and that political clients believe fervently in the truth of their messages, no matter how much those messages may seem like spin to people on the opposite side of the political divide.
 ''There are 20,000 new bills in Congress each year and all of those programs require communications support,'' said Louis Capozzi, chief executive of Manning Selvage & Lee, a unit of Publicis. ''Questions are much more difficult in a political environment because one man's propaganda is another man's truth.''
 Or, as in Mr. Williams's case, another man's controversy. Omnicom initially said that Ketchum had done nothing wrong and that it was Mr. Williams's responsibility to disclose his federal financing.
 ''We would assume that the commentator-pundit would disclose,'' said Lorraine Thelian, Omnicom's head of North American operations, in a January interview with PRWeek, a trade publication. ''That's an assumption that you make.
 ''It's not like we were pitching him to other media as a spokesperson,'' Ms. Thelian added. ''Whatever he did once that contract was put together, he did on his own.''
 Since Omnicom made this statement, it and Ketchum have remained silent, a risky tactic given that public relations wisdom traditionally holds that staying quiet during a crisis only prolongs media scrutiny and creates an appearance of culpability.
 ''They should have come clean right away and not tried to pin all of this on Williams,'' said Paul A. Argenti, a professor of corporate communications at the Tuck School of Business at Dartmouth. ''It's an example of the same kind of bad advice they give their clients every day.''
 Many in the public relations field, meanwhile, say their industry's future hinges on the values that Mr. Williams has espoused in his media appearances: ethics and responsibility.
 ''It's an opportunity for people in the industry to stand up and say, 'Here's the right way to do things, here's the ethical way to do things, and we're in a very new media world and we need to map out a new course of action,''' said Judy Phair, president of the Public Relations Society of America, another trade group. ''For public relations to be effective, it has to be built on public trust.''

HEADLINE: If Jacksonville Seemed an Unusual Super Bowl Spot, Wait Until Next Year

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR

 BODY:
Had Norman Mailer gone to the Super Bowl last Sunday, he might have asked, ''Why are we in Jacksonville?'' 
 Jacksonville (below), in northern Florida, was not a Vietnam-like quagmire, but in the view of news media critics, it was too small, too chilly, too dull, too anonymous, too undeserving to play host to a Super Bowl. This was for warm-weather party cities like Miami, New Orleans and Los Angeles, where 24 of the 39 games have been played. 
 And the National Football League, as travel agent, has another surprise for next year. The Super Bowl is going to another atypical destination: Detroit.
 So is the N.F.L. renouncing its past? Not entirely. The big game will be in Miami in 2007 and Phoenix in 2008. But its criteria have changed, partly to reward cities and owners for paying for new stadiums, like Alltel in Jacksonville and Ford Field in Detroit.
 ''Each of those communities built stadiums, and that's important,'' said the N.F.L. commissioner, Paul Tagliabue. ''When people invest public money in the N.F.L., they get a return, and the Super Bowl is part of the return, when we can do it.''
 The philosophy pleases officials in Detroit, which is bigger than Jacksonville and doesn't need to import cruise ships, as the Florida city did, to meet the N.F.L.'s requirements for hotel rooms.
 ''It's not often they come north, but a lot of fans are from up north, and football is a cold-weather sport,'' said Brad R. Van Dommelen, a senior vice president at the Detroit Metro Convention and Visitors Bureau. He added: ''Safety should not be a concern.''
 It should be noted that Ford Field is a domed stadium. But Detroit is not exactly a resort destination. Its murder rate is rising, its population is shrinking and its unemployment rate is at 14 percent. Even its mayor, Kwame M. Kilpatrick, recently said, ''We've been a black eye on the landscape of America for too long.'' Not exactly an advertisement for next year's Super Bowl.
 RICHARD SANDOMIR

HEADLINE: Those Family Ties Can Bind, But They Can Also Strangle

BYLINE: By DAVID KOEPPEL

 BODY:
After more than 60 years in business, things were beginning to unravel for Arnold's Factory Supplies, a family-run Baltimore company founded in 1933. 
 The longtime president died in 1995, leaving the company without a clear succession plan and precipitating a struggle between the late president's son, Mick Arnold, and another family member. After several years of ''butting heads,'' as Mr. Arnold puts it, the other family member -- whose name and relationship Mr. Arnold asked not be published -- resigned in 1999, and the two relatives have not spoken since. 
 ''The company's survival was at stake, and we were going in the wrong direction,'' said Mr. Arnold, 34, now the sole family member running the 40-employee company, which makes industrial packaging materials. ''I was not going to watch 65 years go down the drain.''
 Such rifts are not uncommon in family-run businesses, according to consultants who specialize in them. In recent years, more attention has been paid to what distinguishes family operations from nonfamily businesses and how they can improve as workplaces for both family members and outsiders. 
 That new focus partly reflects the economic importance of family-run operations -- they account for more than 80 percent of the country's businesses and employ about 62 percent of the American work force, according to The Family Business Review, a Boston journal.
 Moreover, as baby boomers start to retire, many of those businesses are likely to change hands. A survey done in 2003 by the MassMutual Financial Group and the Raymond Family Business Institute estimated that leadership of 39 percent of family businesses would change hands from then to 2008. 
 The advantages of family businesses -- and a reason many people enjoy working for them -- is that they tend to be less bureaucratic than larger organizations and allow employees greater flexibility in making decisions. On the downside, upward mobility can be limited, because many top jobs are held by relatives. 
 ''It's essential for nonfamily members to realize that as outsiders, they are playing by a different set of rules,'' said Jane Zalman of Zalman Family Business Solutions, a consulting firm in New York. Ms. Zalman said that emotions run high under family ownership, whether it is the mom-and-pop business on the corner or a large corporation, and the professional and the personal can often become indistinguishable. 
 She also said that siblings who work together often have a way of communicating that dates back to childhood -- a kind of insider code that outsiders cannot share. 
 Ken Potter Jr., president and chief operating officer of Martin's Potato Chips, a family-run business in Thomasville, Pa., says that he is able to anticipate his family's thoughts even before they speak. And communication among the Potters -- Mr. Potter shares ownership with his younger brothers, Kevin and David -- can be blunt. 
 ''I realize I'm not the only person here and things don't always come out my way,'' said Mr. Potter, who is known as Butch, in part to distinguish him from his father, Ken Sr., who ran the company from 1971 until his retirement last year. 
 Mr. Potter, 44, graduated from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy, N.Y., with a degree in chemical engineering and was working for Nestle in Pennsylvania when his father persuaded him to join the family business. 
 Mr. Potter recalled that his early years at the company were not easy. He felt overloaded with what seemed like too much responsibility and acknowledged that he was ''in over my head.'' Besides managing an operation with about 140 employees, he had to overcome the perception of favoritism -- a fact of life in most family businesses, consultants say.
 Another fact of family enterprises is that personal squabbles are sometimes played out in the office, to the dismay of both nonfamily and family employees.
 ''There's no greater thrill than sharing success with people you love,'' said Paul Karofsky, president of the Transition Consulting Group, a Boston firm, and executive director emeritus of the Northeastern University Center for Family Business. ''But there's no greater hell on earth than working with a dysfunctional family when things aren't going well.'' 
 Mr. Karofsky advises family owners to hire outside executives and set up more corporate structure to give both family and nonfamily employees a better idea of what is expected from them. 
 Consultants can help set up succession plans, make formal the processes for conflict resolution and peer review, and establish clear roles and responsibilities for family employees. 
 Scott Bardell, 46, an account executive for Wagner Printing, a 151-year-old family business with offices in Chicago and Freeport, Ill., has worked for three family-owned printing businesses in the last 15 years, and says he has enjoyed having closer access to management than he might have in larger nonfamily corporations. ''I'm not just a number to a C.E.O.,'' he said. 
 But before joining Wagner, Mr. Bardell left a larger family printing business in the same area after a promised promotion did not materialize. ''After five years, I was told by my boss that he didn't see an opportunity coming up,'' Mr. Bardell recalled. '''Management is top-heavy,' he told me. 'There's too many family members involved to make room.'''
 Gerry Burkhalter, Wagner's production manager, has worked with three generations of Wagner progeny for 39 years and sits on the company's board. He says the family has given him a great deal of autonomy, although he acknowledged that favoritism was still inevitable. He noted, however, that a relative who was hired for a certain job despite a lack of qualifications did not last long. 
 Mr. Arnold of Arnold's Factory Supplies says his company cannot afford ''the luxury of having family hangers-on.'' 
 ''Whether you're name is Arnold or Jones, you have to contribute or you can't be here,'' he said.
 At some family companies, upward movement -- even a stake in the business -- is possible. At Martin's Potato Chips, for example, which is slowly evolving from a down-home Pennsylvania company to a regional food producer that sells snack food in six states, the Potter brothers put their chief financial officer on the board and gave him a minority ownership stake. 
 Mr. Karofsky, the consultant, says family-run companies are increasingly hiring outside managers. But Mr. Potter of Martin's says that his family will never give up day-to-day management. 
 ''The trust is better among family,'' he said. ''I know everyone is working in their self-interest and giving it their best.''

HEADLINE: Free Money? Sure. Heard of Food Stamps?

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED

 BODY:
With techniques like screaming television commercials, Matthew Lesko has built a lucrative business empire that produces nationally sold books of information about ''free money'' that, their covers and his commercials suggest, is available from the government -- in great volume.
 ''Free Money to Quit Your Job,'' ''Free Money to Change Your Life,'' ''Free Money for Entrepreneurs,'' ''Free Money to Pay Your Bills'': They are among the 100 or so works, often the size of telephone books and often with DVD and tape spinoffs, that Mr. Lesko has published over the last two decades. 
 But now the New York State government has given Mr. Lesko something free that he is not shouting about with glee: an accusation that his directories of government money sources offer far less than promised. 
 The criticism, in a recent report by the state's Consumer Protection Board, is based on its examination of one of Mr. Lesko's current volumes, ''Free Money to Pay Your Bills,'' a 772-page compilation that costs $37.95.
 The chairwoman of the Consumer Protection Board, Teresa A. Santiago, charged that the book helped foster a myth that the government had billions in ''hidden money,'' making people susceptible to swindlers promising government grants for an upfront fee. The board forwarded its complaint to the state attorney general's office, where it is being reviewed, an official said.
 Speaking by telephone from the Rockville, Md., offices of his company, Information USA, Mr. Lesko responded that ''Free Money to Pay Your Bills,'' which he compiled with Mary Ann Martello, and his other books had helped many people get aid from programs they had not known existed, and that he was not responsible for the swindlers.
 He granted that he was ''subject to hyperbole'' in promoting his books -- he wears gaudy suits with dollar signs emblazoned on them in his commercials -- but insisted that this did not detract from their value. 
 The cover of ''Free Money to Pay Your Bills'' says that inside are ''over 4,000 little-known government money programs that you can use to pay your bills and get out of debt.'' Also on the cover is an illustration of Mr. Lesko, dressed as Uncle Sam and merrily thrusting out a fistful of dollar bills.
 A spokesman for the Consumer Protection Board, Jon Sorensen, said that ''you might find 400 programs,'' and that many are well known, like unemployment insurance and food stamps. Those that are not well known, he said, can be so restricted in eligibility criteria as to be useless to the general public. For example, there is a program listed that aids a small number of classical music students and retired musicians in New York.
 Mr. Lesko defended his tally of the programs included in the book. ''If you have a federal program that adds money to a state program,'' he said, ''I don't know that it's the same program.'' Nor is it true that everyone knows about the major programs, he said. 
 Mr. Lesko said he included programs that had restricted eligibility requirements to provide a complete directory. 
 He declined to say how much his business had made, saying ''It's nobody's business'' because it is a private company. 
 Happy customers he cited included Terry Brown-Zapata of Woodbridge, Va., who said in an interview that ''Free Money to Pay Your Bills'' had guided her to a county agency that paid for a new furnace and to an internship program that led to a civilian job with the Army. The book gave her information ''I'd have known nothing about,'' she said.
 But Mr. Sorensen pointed to Cathy Boone of Rockville Centre, N.Y., who said that Mr. Lesko's books about starting a business had ''made it sound easy,'' but had wasted her time because the programs did not exist at the places listed or had requirements that a novice like her could not meet.
 Earlier this month, Mr. Lesko modified his credentials on his Web site, lesko.com, which described him, as his books did, as a columnist for Good Housekeeping Magazine and The New York Times Syndicate. He wrote the magazine column in the 1980's and the column for the syndicate from 1992 to 1994. Both organizations recently told him that these did not justify his suggestion of a current association, so the Web site now identifies him as a former columnist for them.

HEADLINE: For Blacks in Law School, Can Less Be More?

BYLINE: By ADAM LIPTAK

 BODY:
ONE would have thought, given the decades of ardent debate over affirmative action in higher education, that the main axes of the dispute had been established. Defenders of racial preferences say that they compensate for historical wrongs, ensure vibrant and varied campus discourse and help create minority role models and leaders. Opponents say preferences are nothing but a reverse form of discrimination that stereotypes and stigmatizes minority students.
 But a recent study published in The Stanford Law Review by Richard H. Sander, a law professor at the University of California, Los Angeles, has found a new way to inflame the debate. In fact, the study has ignited what may be the fiercest dispute over affirmative action since 2003, when the Supreme Court found some forms of it to be constitutional. 
 Professor Sander's study tests a simple, but startling, thesis: Affirmative action actually depresses the number of black lawyers, because many black students end up attending law schools that are too difficult for them, and perform badly. 
 If black law students were accepted to lesser law schools under race-blind admissions, Professor Sander writes, they would receive better grades and pass the bar in greater numbers. Even accounting for the many black students who could not attend any law school without affirmative action, the ultimate number of black lawyers would still increase, he concludes.
 That assertion, which is based on a great deal of data, along with inference and speculation, has provoked an outpouring of written critiques from law professors, economists and social scientists. Several will be published in The Stanford Law Review's May issue. 
 Professor Sander, who is white, says he came to his conclusion reluctantly. He notes that he helped found a fair-housing group in Southern California and that his son is biracial. He says he ''favors race-conscious strategies in principle, if they can be pragmatically justified.''
 His critics generally accept, and sometimes even praise, aspects of his empirical work. He shows three large gaps between black and white students: their academic credentials before entering law school, their grades in law school and their success on bar examinations.
 But many critics dispute Professor Sander's assertion that the first gap -- in undergraduate grades and L.S.A.T. scores -- causes the next two, in law school grades and in rates of passing the bar. 
 The basic numbers are not in serious dispute. 
 Using a standard 1,000-point scale to reflect both L.S.A.T. scores and undergraduate grade-point averages, Professor Sander writes, the average black student's score was 130 to 170 points below that of the average white student.
 Once at law school, the average black student gets lower grades than white students: 52 percent of black students are in the bottom 10th of their first-year law school classes, while only 8 percent are in the top half. And the grades of black students drop slightly in relative terms from the first year of law school to the third.
 Black students are twice as likely as whites to fail to finish law school. Nineteen percent of the black students who started law school in 1991 had failed to graduate five years later; the corresponding figure for whites was 8 percent.
 About 88 percent of all law students pass a bar exam on the first attempt; 95 percent pass eventually. For blacks, the corresponding figures are 61 percent and 78 percent.
 Timothy T. Clydesdale, who teaches sociology at the College of New Jersey, says the law school environment, and not affirmative action, suppresses the grades of some law students. 
 ''Something intrinsic to the structure or process of legal education affects the grades of all minorities,'' he writes in the fall issue of Law and Social Inquiry. Professor Clydesdale agrees with Professor Sander, however, that bar passage rates are determined primarily by law school grades.
 Professor Sander concedes that 14 percent fewer black students would enter law school without preferences. But because more of those who do get in would get good grades at schools that are better suited to them, more would graduate, he said, yielding 8 percent more black lawyers.
 The critics run their own numbers and conclude that without affirmative action, the number of black lawyers would fall anywhere from 9 percent to 35 percent.
 James Lindgren, a law professor at Northwestern who has followed the debate, cautioned that none of these numbers should be taken seriously.
 ''In the real world, too many things would change,'' he said in an interview.
 Professor Sander's study may be most vulnerable in its assessment of the top law schools, where the vast majority of law students of all races graduate and pass the bar.
 For instance, Richard O. Lempert, a law professor at the University of Michigan, said that the university's law school had found little difference between its black and white students in rates of graduation, in passing the bar or in income afterward. ''We think the fact that Michigan is an elite law school has a lot to do with it,'' he wrote in an e-mail message. ''Sander's data, though he barely mentions it, convey essentially the same story. Thus his analysis provides no case for the Harvards, Yales and Columbias of this world to abandon affirmative action.''
 But the situation may be different at less prestigious schools.
 Ian Ayres and Richard Brooks, two Yale Law School professors who are harshly critical of other aspects of the Sander study, used its data for their own study of law schools, which showed that 41.2 percent of black law students -- based on their undergraduate credentials and the law schools they attend -- have less than a fifty-fifty chance of becoming lawyers. The corresponding number for whites is 0.2 percent. ''For some of these people,'' they write in a draft critique, ''the investment in law school seems riskier than getting married in Las Vegas.''
 ''While we reject Sander's conclusion that affirmative action has reduced the number of black attorneys,'' Professors Ayres and Brooks write, ''we are more sympathetic to his idea that there is a class of black law students who shouldn't have gone to law school.''
 Wherever the debate ultimately leads, said Ed Johnson, a research economist at the Bureau of Labor Statistics, Professor Sander's overall hypothesis is a valuable step in trying to understand a complex phenomenon.
 ''His story does seem to fit the data pretty well,'' Mr. Johnson said. ''That doesn't mean it's true. But it's hard to come up with an alternative explanation. In his favor, he's told a story that's at least a story.''

HEADLINE: 'Affordable' Housing, a Moving Target

BYLINE: By TOM CLAVIN

DATELINE: EAST HAMPTON 

 BODY:
LATE last summer, the Town of East Hampton thought it had a good plan to preserve lower-cost housing in a market that was bolting into the stratosphere.
 The town would bottom-feed the real estate market, where the entry-level price for a home was about $400,000. It would put down $150,000 toward each purchase, while beneficiary families, selected by lot from a list of qualified applicants, would secure a mortgage for the $250,000 difference and be handed the keys to their new home. When it came time to resell a house, its price was to be tied to the Consumer Price Index, not to real estate market prices, so the owners could have some modest return on their investment while keeping the home in the ''affordable housing'' range for the next qualified family.
 But now that the town has begun trying to spend the $1.5 million it budgeted to invest in 10 houses for the program, there aren't any houses to be had for $400,000. Town officials are debating whether to boost its appropriation in the program, spending more per house, or to invest in fewer houses, or to require qualified families to get bigger mortgages, or to give up the program altogether and spend the money to build apartments. 
 ''The market is red hot and that's killing us,'' said Tom Ruhle, the director of housing and community development for the town. ''We are being outbid for houses that we're trying to buy.''
 Using data from the Suffolk Research Service, the inflation-adjusted median home sale price in East Hampton Town rose from $274,000 in 2000 to $625,000 in 2004.
 ''The East End and East Hampton in particular have lost gravity,'' said Harold Shepherd, owner of the East Hampton real-estate company that bears his name. ''Whatever goes up, goes up, up and further up. Every time I think a former $200,000 house is going to sell for a million, and that's amazing enough, it sells for a million and a quarter.
 ''The land has gone,'' Mr. Shepherd continued. ''There is no land. It's simple supply and demand. With a small and eventually nonexistent inventory, if I've got it and you want it, you're going to pay whatever I tell you. And unlike Florida and most other areas in the U.S. where you can go north or east or west, there's nowhere else to go in the Hamptons. We're surrounded by water.''
 As a result some residents are finding that buying a house on the South Fork is approaching ''Mission Impossible'' proportions.
 ''I would say that about 80 percent of the year-round residents on the East End could not afford the house they are living in now,'' said Assemblyman Fred Thiele, who was raised in Sag Harbor and continues to live there. ''You look at the demographics and there is continuing to be a large exodus of the younger population, who in the past would emerge as the next middle-class generation here.
 ''I've talked to small business owners who can't find people to hire,'' Mr. Thiele said. ''School districts are having a harder time finding teachers because they can't live here. For police departments and fire departments, there are fewer people stepping up. How are you going to get people to work on Main Street if they can't find a place to live?''
 He added: ''What's especially troublesome is that the gap is widening. The gap between what year-round people's incomes are and what they can afford in the real estate market is growing wider, and at a faster rate.''
 Barbara Weinman is a mother of three and a vice president at Harold Shepherd Real Estate. ''I wouldn't be able to live here now and raise my children,'' she said, ''and I'm lucky. I've lived here 21 years and bought my house 7 years ago. The irony is, if I hadn't been in real estate, I could not have supported my family. I see women all the time at the doctor's office or wherever who are saying, 'We don't know if we can afford to keep living here.' The real estate situation has overturned their whole lives.''
 The housing-subsidy program was meant to make a dent in the problem. In 2003, the Town Board selected by lottery 100 names from the 272 residents who had applied for ''affordable'' housing. Fifty of those names belonged to people eligible for the town's preference list, which included emergency services workers, volunteer firefighters and employees of the town and its school districts. The chosen 100 are being ranked according to their ability to get a mortgage or afford the rent, and Mr. Ruhle said that as units become available, winners will be drawn alternately from the preferred-50 list and the other-50 group.
 There was concern that families who could qualify for a mortgage of $250,000 would exclude the neediest, but Mr. Ruhle was careful to warn that the program was not for low- or very-low-income people. ''We know they wouldn't qualify,'' he said. ''This is for middle-class families who can qualify in partnership with the town.''
 The town does not have specific income parameters for a family to become eligible for the program. ''If you earn $20,000 a year, you're below the cut, and if you make over $100,000, you're probably over the line,'' Mr. Ruhle said. ''What we look at is if a family can secure a mortgage of $250,000. There are many variables involved, including the size of the family, its credit history, cash on hand and current debts. That is why we determine eligibility on a case-by-case basis.''
 Diana Weir, a former East Hampton councilwoman who is now vice president of the Long Island Housing Partnership, said that the Village of Patchogue has purchased downtown property to build an ''affordable housing'' project, and that the Town of Huntington created a town house development in Huntington Station in which the town retained ownership of the land. 
 But a town buying existing homes is unusual. ''Elsewhere on Long Island the focus is building affordable housing,'' Mr. Ruhle said. ''Here, the focus is on buying existing houses.''
 Ms. Weir said: ''Some people don't believe we should be helping people profit at the expense of the taxpayer. Yet we need our work force and young families to stay for economic reasons. In the 1990 to 2000 period, Long Island lost over 127,000 people between the ages of 20 and 34.''
 After the proposal was given to the Town Board, it set aside $3 million in its Community Housing Opportunity Fund. Half would go toward the purchase of 10 properties, and the remaining $1.5 million would underwrite the construction of 26 rental units at a town-owned site in Springs. The town also wants to go ahead with an earlier plan to build 26 homes near the town airport.
 ''We're very much in favor of the buying and renting approach,'' said Sheila Okin of the Amagansett Citizens Advisory Committee. ''But there's only so much money the town can put into the Opportunity Fund, and as the money trickles in, property prices here are rising rapidly.''
 Opposition to the house-buying plan has come from the town's own Community Housing Opportunity Fund Committee. ''Our advice to the town is, don't get involved in real estate,'' said Amado Ortiz, a member of the advisory committee, which was appointed by the Town Board. ''The way house values are in East Hampton today, $150,000 won't go very far, so we could end up with that $1.5 million buying 5 or 6 houses instead of 10. Our preference is to use the entire $3 million to create rental units which will house many more people.
 ''We're happy that there is $3 million available to devote to affordable housing, and that whatever form it takes, it's going to happen,'' he added. ''We just don't think we're getting the most for those bucks by the town buying houses and essentially becoming landlords. The committee is unanimous that rental is the way to go. More people and families can be housed. We have a very big group of single people, such as senior citizens, who don't need a house but an apartment would be fine.'' 
 Though he has yet to buy a single house, Mr. Ruhle is forging ahead. ''We are actively involved in finding houses and land and making offers on them,'' he said. ''That's what we do. That's what we'll continue to do. We're making what we believe are reasonable offers.''

HEADLINE: A Hamlet Allowed to Grow at Its Own Pace

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

 BODY:
MARSHA AND EDWARD LAMADRID took the less-traveled route to suburbia: first they raised two sons in an apartment in Astoria, Queens; then, as empty-nesters, they moved to a quiet neighborhood of single-family homes in Tappan, a hamlet of Orangeburg in Rockland County.
 ''Typically people in Queens go east on Long Island when they move to the suburbs,'' said Mrs. Lamadrid, a clerk for the Bronx Supreme Court. ''When we finally decided to trade in one lifestyle for another, we took off in a different direction.'' 
 When they were looking for a place to move to, they became smitten with the prospect of a direct commute to their jobs in the Bronx, and with the relative affordability of real estate in Rockland compared with some other suburbs. So they headed north. 
 Since the Lamadrids bought their two-bedroom town house condo 14 years ago, one of their grown sons, Daniel, and his wife, Veronica, also relocated from Queens to Tappan. Seven years ago, they bought a 1960's three-bedroom ranch in one of the hamlet's housing developments, later buying a larger home. 
 ''We're all glad to be out of the city,'' Daniel Lamadrid said. 
 During the week, the senior Mr. Lamadrid and his wife commute separately down the Palisades Interstate Parkway to the George Washington Bridge. ''Twenty miles door to door, and less than an hour on most days,'' Mrs. Lamadrid said. ''Not bad.''
 Located in southern Rockland, directly on the New Jersey-New York border, Tappan is one of seven unincorporated sections of Orangetown. Often referred to as hamlets, unincorporated areas do not have their own elected officials. 
 Thom Kleiner, the supervisor of Orangetown, observed that Tappan, a suburb never directly served by a commuter railroad, avoided ''the fate of overdevelopment'' some other communities experienced. ''The lack of a good rail network has had its pluses and its minuses,'' Mr. Kleiner said. ''Basically, it allowed Tappan, which is the southernmost town in the state west of the Hudson, to develop at a more leisurely pace.''
 The Tappan Zee Bridge was not completed until 1955, and before that, Mr. Kleiner said, ''there really was no way to get across the Hudson.'' The George Washington Bridge notwithstanding, he said, there were few north-south roads conducive to a daily commute by car until the Palisades Parkway -- which runs from Fort Lee, N.J., through Rockland to Bear Mountain -- was completed in the mid-1950's. 
 For public transportation, New Jersey Transit's Pascack Valley Line runs commuter trains on weekdays between Spring Valley and Hoboken, N.J., and Red and Tan/Rockland Coaches operates buses between Rockland and locations in New York City. 
 Tappan bears the imprint of two distinct groups of settlers: the Europeans who arrived in the 1600's and the New York City dwellers who moved to the hamlet in the second half of the 1900's.
 The transplants from the city settled in new ranch- and colonial-style houses in developments built 30 and 40 years ago. In addition to the tract housing, which sprawls throughout much of Tappan, the hamlet has three condominium complexes. A small stock of older single-family Victorians and Cape Cods is scattered on smaller lots.
 By contrast, the Village Green, a designated historic area, is a reminder of Tappan's role in the Revolutionary War. Located in the southeastern portion of the hamlet and settled by the Dutch in the 17th century, the area became an intense focus of activity during the latter part of the following century. 
 In 1774, the Orangetown Resolutions, which threatened to repeal English laws like the tea tax that curbed American liberty, were signed there. Close by, the DeWint House, where Gen. George Washington had military quarters, still stands. Also extant and in operation is the Old '76 House, a tavern where Maj. John Andre, the English spy, was held before his hanging in 1780.
 Today that area of the hamlet consists of several blocks of wood-framed homes, small office buildings and enterprises like a pet-grooming establishment and a coffee shop, most of them in structures from the early 1900's.
 The elder Lamadrids were first introduced to Tappan by co-workers in the Bronx, who claimed real estate values were better in Rockland than elsewhere. That is a commonly held notion, although agents in Rockland said it is too difficult to make precise comparisons because of variables like lot sizes and square footage of houses.
 ''At least the perception has been that you get more bang for your buck in Rockland,'' said Jeanne Shields, the manager of Weichert Realtors in Nanuet. ''But whether that really is the case, I don't know. Certainly compared to Westchester, it's a better deal.'' 
 In suburbs outside New York City, the median sales prices for single-family homes vary widely. Nassau County's median reached $437,000 and Suffolk's $362,000 at the end of December, according to the Multiple Listing Service of Long Island. In Westchester, the median for a single-family home was $615,000 at the end of last year, according to the Westchester-Putnam Multiple Listing Service.
 The Rockland County Board of Realtors reported a median of $457,650 for the last three months of 2004. In Tappan, the median price was $500,066, about 9 percent more than for Rockland as a whole, Mrs. Shields said.
 There are other reasons for moving to Tappan, like the quaint charm of the area around the Green.
 After hearing about a 130-year-old clapboard office building for rent in the historic district, David Englander, a lawyer, decided to move his offices from 57th Street in Manhattan to Tappan. Instead of driving an hour or more through rush-hour traffic to get home, Mr. Englander pulls up to his front door in nearby Palisades within six minutes of leaving his cozy office with its wood floors, high windows and elaborate moldings.
 Another businessman, Jerry Hong, a pharmacist, worked on the Upper East Side of New York City for 20 years before he decided to buy Storino Pharmacy in Tappan five years ago. In contrast to Mr. Englander, Mr. Hong now has a much longer commute, driving an hour and 15 minutes each way to and from his home in Brooklyn. ''But it's worth it to me,'' he said. ''The business atmosphere here is much less pressured than it is in the city, the people are more easygoing, and I like being the only pharmacy in town.''
 The South Orangetown Central School District has also served as a magnet. Its students fared well on the SAT's last spring: a mean of 534 on the verbal part of the test and 561 and the math portion, above the statewide average last year of 496 for verbal and 510 for math.
 The school district uses the Princeton plan, a system in which all students in the same grade attend the same school. South Orangetown has 3,578 students in five schools: a high school for Grades 9-12; a middle school for Grades 6, 7 and 8; and three elementary schools, one for Grades 4 and 5, one for Grades 2 and 3, and one for pre-kindergarten through first grade. 
 The Princeton plan, first used in Princeton, N.J., in an attempt to achieve racial integration, was instituted in the South Orangetown schools in the early 1980's to overcome socio-economic differences that previously existed in the separate hamlets and villages, said Jane Sandbank, assistant superintendent for curriculum and instruction. 
 One open question among residents is how to pronounce Tappan. Some say it is Tap-PAN, while others prefer TAP-pan, as in the Tappan Zee Bridge. So far, a consensus has not been reached.
 Even Mr. Kleiner could not offer a solution. 
 ''I thought I knew, but I guess I'm not sure these days,'' Mr. Kleiner said. ''That's something we'll have to settle at a later date.'' 
 For now, the supervisor said he is focusing his energies on further enhancing the charm of the Village Green. The town is spending $750,000 to remove overhead utility wires on nearby streets and reroute them to the rear of buildings, and to install brick pavers on crosswalks and sidewalks. ''The goal is to make one of Rockland's prettiest assets even more picturesque,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Trying Out a Power Source of the Future

BYLINE: By VALERIE COTSALAS

 BODY:
AS a fuel cell housed in a metal box about the size of a small S.U.V. hummed quietly in the parking lot of the Babylon Town Hall with puffs of steam floating out of its exhaust pipe, the chairman of the Long Island Power Authority, Richard Kessel, announced early this month that the utility was seeking a company to build and operate a 10-megawatt fuel cell that would provide enough energy to power 10,000 homes. 
 ''This will be the first project of its kind in America,'' Mr. Kessel said of the plan to feed fuel cell energy directly to the power grid. ''We're taking fuel cells to a new level.''
 Fuel cells are ''clean'' energy generators that convert hydrogen to electricity by a chemical process, requiring no combustion. The exhaust is water, heat and some carbon dioxide. Currently, most fuel cells extract the hydrogen from natural gas. 
 The proposed plant, to be situated at a substation in West Babylon, is to replace a ''farm'' of 75 smaller fuel cells now being tested there. LIPA does not expect homeowner electricity rates to increase as a result of the new project, Mr. Kessel said, even though fuel cells generate electricity at a higher cost than combustion generators.
 Three days after the announcement, in the quiet living room of a house in West Islip, Sister Gertrude O'Brien flipped a switch on the reading lamp over her easy chair. The lamp, one of several appliances in the house powered by the fuel cell sitting in the middle of the backyard, dutifully lighted the room. ''I think it's kind of ugly,'' Sister Gertrude said of the bulky fuel cell out back, ''but I would say that the benefits greatly outweigh the aesthetics.''
 Those benefits were visible on a day in December when a car hit a utility pole nearby. The whole neighborhood lost power, but Sister Gertrude and the two other nuns who live in the house could turn on their lights and watch television.
 Next door, when the Rev. Douglas Dower returned to his home that same night, he noticed all the homes on his block were dark. When he got inside, he checked his appliances.
 ''When I opened the refrigerator door, the light went on and everything inside was still cold,'' Father Dower said.
 The fuel cell in his yard, hooked up through conduits and pipes in the cellar to provide heat, light and power to essential appliances in his home, did not need the LIPA grid.
 Sister Gertrude and Father Doug, as they are called at Good Samaritan Hospital where they both work, live in hospital-owned homes that are two of several fuel cell test sites across the Island. Others include buildings at Brookhaven National Laboratory, a McDonald's restaurant and the Babylon Town Hall.
 Baron Davis, who lives with his wife and two young sons in a home they rent in Mineola, first came to live on Long Island from Anchorage, Alaska, in August 2003, landing at Newark Liberty International Airport only 20 minutes after a widespread blackout had knocked out power to most of the East Coast. 
 With nowhere else to go, Mr. Davis rented a car and drove with his sons to the Mineola home where the family had just moved. ''It was a nightmare, I couldn't even see road signs,'' Mr. Davis said of that harrowing six-hour drive. 
 But he is feeling more secure these days. Since early January, Mr. Davis's home has been one of seven in Mineola, owned by Winthrop Hospital, that are powered and heated partly by a fuel cell.
 ''They basically created a ditch and connected pipes over a week,'' he said of the installation by Plug Power Inc., the Albany-based company that manufactured the fuel cells for the tests. ''It really didn't create any problems.''
 The fuel cell power has been more reliable so far. Before the fuel cell was hooked up, the lights in the house would flicker every day, he said, and he often had to reboot his computer.
 ''Ever since they've had this on, I haven't seen any glitches,'' Mr. Davis, an unemployed electrical engineer, said of the fuel cell. ''No lights flickering on and off anymore.'' 
 But fuel cells like those used in Long Island homes are too expensive, about $75,000, and require servicing too often to be a viable residential alternative right now, according to Roger Saillant, president and chief executive of Plug Power. The main function of the tests is to improve the technology.
 ''You can compare it to the combustion engine in a car -- billions have been built, there's an opportunity to learn from each one of them,'' Mr. Saillant said. ''Of all the fuel cells in all the world, there's probably not 2,000 of them.''
 The LIPA plan to use fuel cells to supply the grid is part of an effort to generate 25 percent of the utility's energy using renewable sources by 2014, a goal set by the New York State Public Service Commission last year, Mr. Kessel said. 
 The utility has also already contracted with Florida Power and Light to build a windmill farm -- 40 to 50 windmill turbines -- about six miles from the Island's south shore, near Robert Moses State Park, providing 140 megawatts of power to the grid. Long Island's power demands averaged about 2,989 megawatts per hour in 2004 during peak hours. 
 But while windmills create electricity from ocean winds, the fuel cells used for LIPA's project will use a fossil fuel to operate: natural gas. The public service commission includes fuel cells in its policy, a commission spokesman, David Flanagan, said, to spur on the development of cells that will one day run on renewable resources like methane or electrical current. 
 Gordian Raacke, head of the environmental group Renewable Energy Long Island, discussed the future of fuel cells at the Babylon Town Hall news conference, where he praised LIPA's newest energy project. 
 Mr. Raacke powers his East End home with solar panels. Under a LIPA plan that allows homeowners using solar energy to ''run their meters backward,'' Mr. Raacke feeds electricity back to the grid and gets credits on his electric bill instead of charges. ''I don't pay anything for electricity,'' he said. ''When the day is overcast and I need energy, I use the credits.''
 The fuel cell of the future, Mr. Raacke believes, will be able to extract and store hydrogen from solar- and wind-generated energy, so if he had one in his house, he would not need to tap the grid on a cloudy day. ''Fuel cell technology provides an important link in the alternative energy chain,'' he said. ''It closes the loop.''
 Mr. Saillant of Plug Power said it is indeed possible for fuel cells to store hydrogen gas taken from a mixture of water and the electrical current generated by wind turbines and solar panels. Ideally, the stored gas would be used on a calm or overcast day to continue powering and heating the home.
 But he estimates that fuel cells not requiring natural gas are, under the best federal-financing conditions, at least 15 years away. 
 More recently in Mineola, Mr. Davis is happy with the first month of fuel cell power in his home. ''Having experienced a major outage, I can really appreciate this,'' he said.

HEADLINE: 'New' Rumsfeld Is Seeking Stronger Ties With Europe

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO; Eric Schmitt contributed reporting for this article.

DATELINE: MUNICH, Feb. 12 

 BODY:
Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld returned Saturday to the scene of his most brutal and bitter clash with Europe, which occurred two years ago, suggesting that he was a new man eager to forge a stronger trans-Atlantic relationship in the second Bush administration. 
 ''When I first mentioned I might be traveling in France and Germany, it raised some eyebrows,'' he joked in his speech at the annual Munich Conference on Security Policy. ''One wag said it ought to be an interesting trip after all that has been said. I thought for a moment and then I replied, 'Oh, that was the old Rumsfeld.''' 
 The line got a laugh from the audience of specialists on European and American national security, business and politics. 
 In the same grand 19th-century hotel in February 2003, Mr. Rumsfeld enraged much of Europe by branding as ''Old Europe'' opponents of the American-led invasion of Iraq, most prominently France and Germany. His reception last year at the conference was less icy, but this year, it was even, at times, warm.
 His appearance was only decided late Thursday, and it seemed intended to reinforce Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice's message on her recent European tour to convince America's traditional allies that the United States takes them seriously. The Europeans are so hungry for attention and respect from Washington that some participants said that the fact that Mr. Rumsfeld showed up at all was important. 
 But while Mr. Rumsfeld joked and smiled on his charm offensive in Europe, he had no new policy substance. 
 Most pointedly, when Germany called on the United States on Saturday to support European negotiations to persuade Iran to abandon a crucial part of its nuclear program, Mr. Rumsfeld refused to endorse the initiative.
 In the opening speech to the conference, Germany appealed to the United States to end Iran's isolation, arguing that only economic and security incentives could persuade Iran to abandon a crucial part of its nuclear program.
 ''I strongly encourage the U.S. administration to actively support the Europeans' diplomatic efforts,'' Defense Minister Peter Struck of Germany said, speaking in the name of Chancellor Gerhard Schroder, who was ill and could not deliver the speech. ''We must overcome Iran's massive isolation for Iran will only abandon its nuclear ambitions for good if not only its economic but also its legitimate security interests are safeguarded.''
 That will happen, Mr. Struck added, only with American involvement in a regional dialogue. In his speech, Mr. Rumsfeld only briefly mentioned the global problem of weapons proliferation and mentioned neither Iran's nuclear program nor the current standoff with North Korea over its nuclear weapons program. He was not about to weigh in on what is emerging as the most crucial diplomatic issue facing the second Bush administration and Europe.
 Asked in a question-and-answer session afterward to respond to the German call for American support on Iran, Mr. Rumsfeld dodged. 
 ''The president and Secretary Rice have commented on it, and the last thing I want to do is to step on their words,'' he said. ''How's that? I think that pretty well covered it. Next?'' 
 Later, Mr. Rumsfeld said that the United States hoped that the Europeans or the International Atomic Energy Agency, the United Nations' nuclear monitoring organization, ''can proceed on a diplomatic path'' to persuade Iran to abandon what he called its ''seeming path to develop a nuclear weapon.'' He said nothing about direct American support for the Europeans. 
 The United States is convinced that Iran is secretly planning to build nuclear bombs and is struggling to develop a strategy to deal with Iran's Islamic Republic. In a meeting with French intellectuals in Paris on Wednesday, Ms. Rice branded Iran a ''totalitarian'' state and said that any approach that held out incentives for Iran would only help sustain the hard-liners in Iran, participants in the meeting said. 
 On Saturday, Defense Minister Ali Shamkhani appeared on Iranian state television inspecting a torpedo assembly line, Reuters reported. Mr. Rumsfeld only decided to attend the security conference just hours after Germany's federal prosecutor on Thursday rejected calls to investigate accusations that Mr. Rumsfeld and nine other top officials were guilty of war crimes in the Iraqi prisoner abuse scandal.
 ''He did well here by adopting a more congenial style without changing U.S. positions on any major issue,'' said Richard C. Holbrooke, secretary of state for European affairs and ambassador to Germany in the Clinton administration. ''It reflects a return to the proper leadership style for the United States -- to lead in a positive way -- not in a way that alienates the very people you want to follow you.'' 
 But Mr. Rumsfeld's colloquial, fast-talking style did not appeal to everyone. ''He always goes for the good phrase,'' said Josef Joffe, publisher and editor-in-chief of the German daily Die Zeit. ''The more he tries to get a laugh and deliver a punch line, the more he gets himself into trouble.'' His message on NATO, Mr. Joffe added, ''is that it's been dead for a long time.''
 Mr. Rumsfeld told the audience that one nation alone could not defeat radical Islamists and their ''totalitarian'' aims, emphasizing the importance of the NATO alliance. ''It will take many nations to help Afghans and Iraqis succeed in bringing democracy to places where tyrants once ruled and terrorists once trained,'' he said. 
 Still, even as the United States is asking NATO, with limited success, to take on a much larger role in training Iraq's police and military, he made clear that the NATO alliance is limited in what it can do. 
 ''NATO is the most impressive military alliance in the history of mankind, but it is what it is,'' Mr. Rumsfeld said, adding that ''nothing would have happened'' to address crises in places like Liberia or Haiti if the world had waited for NATO. 
 Mr. Schroder, in the speech delivered in his name, surprised participants with his even more critical remarks about NATO, saying that it was ''no longer the primary venue where trans-Atlantic partners discuss and coordinate strategies.'' 
 He called for the creation of a high-ranking panel of specialists to present governments with a reform of trans-Atlantic relations by early 2006 -- but that it should be between the United States and the European Union, not NATO.
