HEADLINE: Fare Increase Is Only a Start At N.J. Transit

BYLINE: By JOHN SULLIVAN

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
DAY after agonizing day in the aftermath of the recent punishing snowstorm and single-digit temperatures -- there were delays, cancellations, equipment failures and overcrowded trains. In retrospect, it was perhaps the worst possible time for New Jersey Transit to ask for a fare increase.
 Still, some longtime passengers like Fran Duffy were philosophical.
 ''Lately it has been terrible, but usually the service is pretty good,'' said Mr. Duffy, who has been commuting to Wall Street from his home in Mercerville for 25 years. 
 Hunched against the cold at the Princeton Junction train station on a recent evening, Mr. Duffy -- whose hour-long commute mutated into a three-hour slog in the days following the snowstorm-- shrugged about the proposed increase in ticket prices.
 ''I am not happy about it,'' he said, ''but what can you do?''
 From the vantage point of New Jersey Transit, the nation's third-largest mass transit system -- which operates 2, 027 buses, 711 rail cars and 45 light-rail cars -- the answer is not much. 
 So the cash-starved agency, which until 2002 had not raised fares in more than a decade, has come back to passengers for the second increase in three years. The reason is simple: without an increase, New Jersey Transit will face a $60 million loss next year.
 Under this year's proposed increase -- which must first be approved by the board of New Jersey Transit before taking effect in April -- the average rail fare will go up about 13 percent, and discounts for traveling during off-peak hours will be cut to 12.5 percent from 25 percent.
 In addition, interstate bus fares will increase 13 percent under the proposal, although the price of monthly passes for local buses will not rise. One-way tickets on local buses, the Newark subway and the South Jersey light rail will go to $1.25 from $1.10, and fares on the Hudson Bergen Light Rail will rise to $1.75 from $1.50. 
 But before the proposed increases are voted on, the transit agency has scheduled 13 public hearings around the state from Feb. 15 through Feb. 26. 
 ''N.J. Transit did not increase fares for many years and now it is catching up with them,'' said Jeffrey Zupan, a transportation expert for the Regional Plan Association in Manhattan. ''The fare is the only thing taxpayers and the public sees; and for many years, they decided politically it made sense not to raise the fares.''
 In fact, before a 10 percent increase in 2002, the agency's last rise in fares, 9 percent, was instituted in July 1990.
 To be sure, public hearings like those scheduled over the next two weeks rarely result in drastic policy shifts -- particularly when an agency has already budgeted for a fare increase. Nonetheless, Jack F. Lettiere, the state Transportation commissioner, said transit officials would consider changes if a convincing case could be made.
 ''It is not just window dressing,'' Mr. Lettiere insisted. ''I am interested in what folks have to say about the pricing structure.''
 Yet this time, transit officials say, an increase is desperately needed to meet a range of expenses like rising fuel prices and skyrocketing health insurance costs for employees. In addition, an increase in security in the aftermath of the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, 2001, has added about $13 million a year to the agency's $1.4 billion budget.
 Even after the proposed increases go into effect, however, officials warn that the system faces more serious financial problems. 
 For starters, the proposed increase will not come close to eliminating the agency's long-term gap between revenues and expenses. And experts warn that unless the state Legislature increases subsidies or financing through a rise in the gasoline tax, New Jersey Transit will face far more serious problems down the road.
 Indeed, New Jersey Transit officials say, unless legislators take some action, the agency could be facing a budget gap of more than $300 million within two years.
 ''This is an issue we are going to have to deal with,'' said Mr. Lettiere, who is also board chairman of New Jersey Transit. 
 To a certain extent, the transit system -- particularly the commuter rail section -- is a victim of its own success. Public transit rarely shows a profit; most systems, including New Jersey Transit, lose money on every customer. Ticket prices only cover about 42 percent of the cost of running the transit lines, according to George Warrington, the executive director of New Jersey Transit. That means for every $10 ticket, the agency has to raise $5.80 from somewhere other than the rider. 
 Moreover, business has been booming on the state's trains and buses. According to figures from New Jersey Transit, the number of passengers has increased by more than 30 percent over the past 10 years.
 ''There is a gap between revenues and expenses,'' Mr. Warrington said. ''And it gets worse as we increase services.''
 All of which has left transit officials in a difficult position. Although experts, including Mr. Lettiere, have said New Jersey Transit will almost certainly have to raise fares steadily to make up for the decade of no increases, they recognize it will be practically impossible for the system to make up the budget shortfall by simply raising prices. To do so would require more than doubling the cost of a ticket, which could drive away customers. In fact, the agency estimates that this proposed increase may lead to a 3 percent drop in ridership.
 The constant scramble for money has led New Jersey Transit to repeat a common sin in the mass transit world: diverting money from long-term repairs to pay for short term operations. Over the past 10 years, for instance, the agency has taken more than $1 billion from long-term projects to keep the trains and buses running.
 But agency officials say they can no longer continue doing this, and are capping the amount of money diverted from long-term repairs at $360 million a year. 
 Indeed, Mr. Warrington said one reason for the fare increase is the agency's decision to limit the amount of money diverted from long-term work. In 2003, a commission appointed by Gov. James E. McGreevey estimated that the state needed to invest an additional $5 billion in long-term repairs to prevent deterioration of the rail and bus systems. Diverting that money from daily operations will only increase future problems, Mr. Warrington said.
 ''It is masking an underlying problem,'' he said. ''It steals your seed corn from investment and basic infrastructure.''
 Since America began its love affair with the automobile, trains have been relegated to the position of jealous suitor. For most rail companies, moving passengers without entering bankruptcy has been impossible for nearly 50 years.
 New Jerey Transit was created from the wreckage of several once mighty passenger rail lines that ran though the state: the Jersey Central, the Erie Lackawanna and the Pennsylvania Railroad. Those companies were losing money on passenger trips by the late 1960's, and the state stepped in with financial support. After a brief period of nationalization -- the railroads were run for a time by Conrail, which was formed in 1976 and sold in 1998 -- New Jersey Transit assumed full control of commuter rail and bus service in 1983. 
 From the beginning, the agency was confronted with a creaking mix of old trains, worn track and decaying switching equipment. Over the next decade, transit officials concentrated on replacing the train cars and locomotives and repairing the tracks.
 As the system improved, demand for service increased, and in the late 1990's, the agency expanded rapidly: a huge switching and track project extended a direct ride into Manhattan for thousands of suburban commuters; a new station at Newark Airport added a direct link for air passengers; a station in Secaucus allowed residents north of Hoboken to ride directly into New York; and two light-rail systems opened, one linking towns along the Hudson, the other connecting Delaware River towns in the south.

New Rail Lines Are Popular
 Although the new operations have experienced some problems -- crowding in particular has been a complaint, and some new equipment has had trouble meshing with antiquated machinery -- they have generally been popular. Ridership has increased on all the lines: from 1991 to 2004, the number of passengers increased by 34 percent. And planning groups like New Jersey Future have found that new rail service has boosted property values. 
 But there was one problem with all of this expansion: New Jersey Transit could not afford to pay for it. 
 Ten years ago, the transit agency began running up large operating deficits, while at the same time, the state Legislature began scaling back on subsidies. From 1994 to 2002, the amount of money provided to the transit system fell. Over the same period -- and not counting the cost of new services -- inflation cost the agency $40 million a year, according to the governor's special transportation commission.
 Governor McGreevey tried to address the problem when he took office, but state budget problems only allowed legislators to return New Jersey Transit subsidies to 1994 levels of $260 million a year.

More Service, Smaller Subsidies
 ''What you really have is N.J. Transit getting less than they got in 1994 if you take into account inflation,'' said Martin E. Robins, director of the Alan M. Voorhees Transportation Center at Rutgers University. 
 To keep the system running, transit officials began to dip into their long-term funds. In 1990, they used $8 million from capital investments to pay for daily maintenance. And as costs increased, the system relied more on long-term financing. By last year, the agency was diverting $360 million each year from long-term projects.
 In a way, moving the money from the long-term side to daily operations is an accounting problem rather than a practical one. State rules separate money for transit into two piles. One, for daily operations, comes from passenger fares and subsidies from state and federal government. The other, from the gasoline tax, pays for long-term repairs and large purchases, including new buses and train cars.
 Essentially, transit officials ran out of money from daily pile and started using money from the gas tax to pay for day-to-day operations.
 The problem, of course, is that long-term repairs do not get finished. It is like using money set aside for roof repairs to pay the electric bill: the lights stay on, but eventually the roof falls in.
 ''You need to ensure a state of good repair for the railroad itself,'' Mr. Lettiere said. ''Once that starts to deteriorate, you have real problems.''
 In general, the agency's buses and train cars are in good shape. The system recently received the last of 30 new electric locomotives, and is adding 26 new diesel engines as well. A fleet of 200 new rail cars has had some problems integrating with older equipment -- doors have stuck closed and intercoms have malfunctioned -- but Mr. Warrington said the manufacturer has promised to finish repairing the cars by this spring. And by 2007, New Jersey Transit is scheduled to begin using double-deck rail cars, increasing capacity by 25 percent without adding new trains to the schedule.
 ''Generally, over 10 years our reliability has improved,'' Mr. Warrington said. ''In any given month we run in the 94-95 percent on-time time range.''
 The problem is the underlying infrastructure. According to the governor's transportation committee report, New Jersey Transit needs to make substantial investments in bridge repairs as well as station and track upgrades. Equipment on buses, like the radio system, also needs to be upgraded.
 The train system also faces serious problems with its most important rail line: the Northeast Corridor, owned by Amtrak, between Washington and Boston. Because Amtrak -- operated by the federal government -- has historically been strapped for funds since the nation's intercity rail service was formed in 1971, much of the track as well as signal and electric equipment are literally falling apart. 
 Mr. Warrington, who was president of Amtrak before coming to New Jersey Transit two years ago, said many of the problems encountered after last month's snowstorm were caused by failing Amtrak equipment. And with President Bush planning to eliminate the $1.2 billion subsidy for Amtrak in his budget introduced last week, the situation is not likely to improve any time soon.
 ''There is clearly a problem developing associated with the basic integrity of the Northeast Corridor,'' Mr. Warrington said. He said the snowstorm demonstrated ''the fragile nature of the Northeast corridor and the difficulty Amtrak has had maintaining it.''
 And while New Jersey Transit's equipment is wearing out, the agency's bank account is in far worse shape, largely because of the meager gas tax collected in the state Transportation Trust Fund.
 Originally, the trust fund was pay-as-you-go: money was collected from the gas tax and spent on highway and transit projects. But about 10 years ago, the state began borrowing against the trust fund as a way to avoid increasing the gas tax. As a result, New Jersey has the fourth lowest gas tax in the United States, but it has run up a huge debt to pay for highway projects.
 By the middle of 2006, the debt will have grown so large that all of the money collected from the gas tax will go toward paying off the state's loans, about $805 million a year. That means there will be no money available to pay for new highway projects -- or any expenses for New Jersey Transit. 
 In turn, transit officials -- who have grown dependent on the money for much of their budget -- say that would be a disaster.
 ''Without the trust fund, we would lose $350 million of a $1.4 billion budget,'' Mr. Warrington said. ''Obviously, that would have very serious consequences.''

Gas Tax Rise Is Inevitable
 Experts assume that the state will rescue the trust fund before it runs out of money, probably by raising the gas tax. Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey, who declined to comment for this article, has said he is willing to consider increasing the tax, though he has said that it is not politically feasible to bring up the issue before the November elections.
 That is largely the result of state politicians' beliefs that voters will punish any public official who dares to raise taxes. In its report two years ago, the governor's commission on transportation said it would be necessary to increase the gas tax as much as 12.5 cents to 15 cents a gallon -- almost doubling the current tax of 14.5 cents -- to repair the state's highways and make improvements to the mass transit system.
 David Rebovich, director of the Institute for New Jersey Politics at Rider University, said the acting governor obviously is concerned that ''opponents would use such an increase as campaign fodder.''
 But Mr. Rebovich said the issue is such a looming concern that candidates will not be able to avoid taking a position. ''Candidates from both parties will be forced to talk about it,'' he said.
 Assemblyman John S. Wisniewski, a Democrat from Bordentown who is chairman of the Transportation Committee, agrees that political leaders should not duck the issue, since the only practical way to raise money for transportation projects is through the gas tax.
 Moreover, Mr. Wisniewski said allowing the Transportation Trust Fund to run out of money would be irresponsible and dangerous for the state's economy.
 ''It is going to be funded and it is going to be funded through an increase in the motor fuels tax,'' said Mr. Wisniewski.
 For now, Mr. Wisniewski said, political leaders need to explain to voters why the gas tax money is needed and convince them that the money will benefit the economy.
 ''So much of our economy is based on transporation,'' he said. ''We need to have an honest dialogue with the people of the state. We need to explain to them what they get for this.''

HEADLINE: Grade Point Angst At Princeton

BYLINE: By ROBERT STRAUSS

 BODY:
LILY JOHNSTON, a psychology major from the Seattle area completing her senior year at Princeton University, is viewed by her teachers as a young woman with a great future. ''She is a high achieving senior and is quite articulate,'' said Samuel Wang, an assistant professor of molecular biology at the university.
 Ms. Johnston is not so sure her future is as secure as others may think. Princeton has just completed its first semester under a new grading policy aimed at reducing the number of A's it awards, the first and only Ivy League school to do so. Ms. Johnston and many other students worry that the new, tougher grading standards will put hurt them as they look for jobs or apply to graduate or professional schools. 
 ''The people in my stage have gone through three years at Princeton getting grades you thought you earned,'' Ms. Johnston said. ''Now, maybe people are saying those grades weren't valid. While I personally didn't notice anything in actual grades last semester, I did notice professors making a point of mentioning the new standards. That changes the tenor of the class, and it makes you think the professor is more conscious of, perhaps, grading down.''
 Dr. Wang, like many of the senior faculty who voted overwhelmingly in favor of those new standards, thinks they will give a greater value to a Princeton 'A.' 
 In April, after much talk at Princeton and other Ivy League schools about grade inflation, the faculty voted 2-to-1 to approve a proposal by Nancy Weiss Malkiel, the dean of the college, to set an expectation that the number of A's handed out by each academic department would be limited to 35 percent of students in regular courses and 55 percent of students doing independent work. Princeton plans to release the results of its new policy at the end of the spring semester, after the first full academic year. 
 Grade inflation has been a concern on college campuses since the Vietnam War, when some professors gave students better grades so they could keep their draft deferments. The issue took on a new urgency after it was reported by The Boston Globe in 2001 that Harvard University awarded honors to 91 percent of its 2001 graduates. At Princeton, between 1997 and 2002, 45.5 percent of all students in undergraduate courses received A's.
 A faculty-staff committee at Princeton that examined grade inflation put the issue succinctly in the opening statement of its 2003 report: ''Who could ever have imagined that we would reach a point where a student with a straight B average would rank 923 out of a graduating class of 1079 -- or where a student with a straight C average would rank 1078?''
 Some smaller academic departments, like Slavic languages, have voiced concern that if A's are parceled out so strictly, students would begin shying away from classes and departments would die. Still other faculty members oppose an arbitrary restriction on the number of A's they can award. But Dr. Wang said the new policy was important to be able to differentiate between students. ''A huge practical issue in grade inflation is the compression of students into a small number of categories. In some departments the range is effectively from A+ to B. This compression makes evaluation of students harder,'' Dr. Wang said.
 Dean Malkiel said the university has sent letters to major graduate schools and as many as 3,000 employers to explain the university's new grading policy. But that has not eased concerns among students.
 Matt Margolin, a senior political science major from Portola Valley, Calif., and the former president of the student government, said: ''All of the Wall Street jobs and major scholarships look at the junior year and first semester senior year grades. There is such a mass of students applying that, at least, the first cut is about those grades and they can't be concerned with a letter explaining Princeton's new position.''
 Mr. Margolin said that he believes that Princeton is a better school with better students than it was in past generations, so higher grades would be justified.
 ''I worked really hard to get in here,'' he said. ''I did 20 drafts of my application essay. I worked really hard in high school. I did all the extra things I needed to get in because I really wanted to be here. My father went to Princeton and I don't think -- he doesn't think -- he could get in here today. Times are different and things are more competitive, so I think most all of those A's were completely legitimate.'' Dr. Wang said students should be less concerned about the grade debate and more concerned about the real world. ''I was dismayed at the high level of student interest in this topic both before and after we passed the proposal,'' he said. ''Last year we saw a heated presidential campaign and escalation of casualties in the Iraq war, but I heard far less from students on these topics. The undergraduate student government wrote all the faculty a letter regarding their opposition to the grade inflation proposal. The Abu Ghraib prison abuses were revealed around that time, a topic about which I heard nothing.''
 So far, the grade-inflation restrictions do not appear to have hurt Princeton's reputation among prospective students. ''Applications to Princeton are up from previous years, so the new initiative does not appear to be discouraging students from coming here,'' said Daniel R. Marlow, a Princeton physics professor. ''I believe that in the long run, this will improve the quality of education at Princeton, and that both faculty and students will end up working harder.''
 Jeffrey Herbst, a 1983 Princeton graduate and now a political science professor there, expects the controversy to blow over. ''The student body refreshes itself completely every four years,'' he said. ''Very soon, it will appear to Princeton students that this policy is the way it has always been.''


GRAPHIC: Photo: Princeton students are worried about the university's new, tougher grading policy, which is meant to cut the number of A's. (Photo by Nancy Wegard for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Down So Long, It Looks Like Up in Trenton

BYLINE: By JOSH BENSON

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
EVEN as New Jersey's leaders have shuttled, year after year, to countless sessions of the Legislature in this city on the Delaware, drug trafficking and violent crime in neighborhoods surrounding the gleaming State House dome have exploded in a rainbow of gang colors. 
 Local and state authorities have had little success combating the trend in recent years, with homicides and sexual assault still a frustratingly common occurrence. Indeed, a national survey recently ranked Trenton, an ethnically diverse city of 85,000, as the fourth-most dangerous city of its size in the country. 
 Yet against this backdrop of lawlessness, some residents say they have reason to hope that help is on the way. 
 ''The police aren't letting the city go anymore,'' said Ken Bullock, a barber and community activist who has lived all of his 47 years in Trenton. 
 Mr. Bullock said he had noticed a much greater police presence in his crime-ridden neighborhood on Walnut Avenue and Monmouth Street, about a mile east of the State House. ''It's been a dramatic change here. They're actually doing something.'' 
 Yet there is a long way to go. Mr. Bullock said that these days, trouble looms in the form of violent, drug-dealing street gangs. And many of his neighbors -- after years of antipathy -- are still wary of the largely white police force. ''You know, most people in Trenton are still scared of the law,'' he said.
 But these days Mr. Bullock is a frequent visitor to police headquarters on North Clinton Avenue, near the city's municipal court, where he says he has discovered a receptive audience.
 Such observations are new for Trenton, a once-thriving industrial center whose neighborhoods have been eroded in recent decades by rising joblessness and crime. Trenton's population has shrunk by nearly a fifth from the more than 104,000 black, Hispanic, Italian, Irish and Polish residents who lived there as late as the 1970's.
 Like many tired cities in the Northeast, the jobs -- and middle-class residents -- moved to nearby suburbs like Hamilton Township. Today, the unemployment rate in Trenton is 10 percent, compared with 4 percent statewide, and more than 17 percent of its families live below the poverty line.
 The public schools, some of which were considered among the best in the state in the 1950's, are now among the worst. A state takeover of the city's affairs in the early 1980's provided little in the way of a long-term solution, nor did construction of new office buildings near the State House, which gave the city a skyline and thousands of state jobs but no tax revenue.
 In the past several years, there have been glimmers of a reawakening. For instance, the Mill Hill section has seen an influx of urban-pioneering gay couples. And the Italian section known as Chambersburg still draws patrons to a handful of well-known restaurants. But there are still other areas around the city that are nothing less than danger zones.
 The city's desperate crime situation has led to some extraordinary measures. Two years ago, Mayor Douglas H. Palmer hired Joseph Santiago, the fiery former Newark police director and state police superintendent, as Trenton's police director. 
 Instead of shying away from Mr. Santiago's controversial past, Mr. Palmer gave him sweeping latitude to impose changes to the 363-member police department, like beefing up the peer review system and forcing officers to spend more time on the streets in the worst neighborhoods. 
 More recently, the city contracted with a consultant on gang intervention to help oversee the coordination of police and city efforts with the public schools to enroll youths in dozens of new outreach and mentoring programs.
 At the same time, the state attorney general's office and state police have taken a larger role in battling gang and drug-related violence. As recently as June, 17 gang leaders were arrested, and others are said to be under investigation. 
 The determined -- if long overdue -- focus on reducing crime in this relatively small city, aided by the political will and an array of new techniques, has crime experts referring to Trenton as an unlikely proving ground for some of the region's most advanced crime-prevention methods.
 ''The size of Trenton and the fact that there's broad political and organizational support for change means that we should have a really unusual opportunity to test what's possible,'' said George L. Kelling, faculty chairman of the Police Institute at Rutgers University in Newark, who is advising city officials here on their new initiatives. ''We might be able to do something that could have a rapid impact and a lot of significance, there and in other cities.''
 For his part, Peter C. Harvey, the state attorney general, did not mince words about what he thought was at stake. ''All of us collectively have to be very consistent in our community education and our law-enforcement effort in Trenton to make sure that our capital city doesn't deteriorate into an uninhabitable city,'' he said. 
 Results have been mixed. On one hand, the city is about to release numbers for last year showing a 17 percent drop in serious crime. According to police officials, there were 5,182 incidents involving homicide, rape, theft, assault and arson, a drop from 6,224 in 2003.
 But a closer look at those numbers shows something less promising: because of drug and gang-related violence, killings have remained stubbornly common occurrences, with 18 homicides last year, up from 13 the year before. There were also 46 incidents of rape reported in 2004, up from 36 in 2003. 
 Moreover, despite a decline in the overall crime rate, which mirrors a statewide trend, certain high-crime neighborhoods in Trenton are still barely livable. In those parts of the city, street gangs seem at times to be ubiquitous: Los Angeles-based groups like the Bloods have taken root in the southern part of Trenton, the police say, while the Crips have flourished in the eastern ward. In addition, new gangs have sprouted in the Hispanic neighborhoods near the maximum-security state prison downtown.
 To the chagrin of city officials who are trying to change the image -- and the reality -- here, Morgan Quitno Press, a Kansas-based research company, ranked Trenton the fourth-most dangerous city of its size in the country. 
 Mr. Santiago, the garrulous law-enforcement veteran who was appointed director of police in February 2003, said that the increase in killings was more a reflection of the gang-related drug trade than the overall safety of the city, and that most neighborhoods had become less dangerous places. 
 He also contended that the department's performance had improved since he arrived by increasing officer accountability, cutting the average response time and raising the police presence on the streets. 
 ''When I got down here, I started asking questions,'' he said. ''I asked about crime rates. They didn't even know what they were. Two years ago, they didn't even have a daily crime report. I asked if there were gangs in Trenton. They said no.''
 Still, he said, he recognized that despite the departmental improvements and apparent drop in overall crime, it was only a start.
 ''We realize there's a long way to go,'' Mr. Santiago said. ''We've started by increasing people's confidence in the police. But we know we have to keep going. '' 
 Much of the next step, which the city hopes to point to as a model, will include new crime-prevention programs. To that end, the city recently hired Barry Colicelli, another veteran of the Newark Police Department, to create programs that would identify and deal with the city's most ''at-risk'' young gang members and juvenile offenders, essentially setting up a system to badger them with alternative educational and mentoring programs. 
 As part of the effort, Mr. Colicelli will be charged with setting up a system of accountability in which officers will question each other about progress in deterring gang recruitment, youth violence and truancy. 
 ''I certainly don't know of anything on this scale that's being done anywhere else,'' Mr. Colicelli said.
 Yet for all of the big plans, there are also big obstacles. For one thing, the politics of policing Trenton remain murky. Mr. Palmer is still reeling from the worst political storm of his 14-year tenure, prompted by his hiring Mr. Santiago, who was forced from his previous job with the state police after several well-publicized controversies. Mr. Santiago, who was never charged with any crime, faced questions about his personal finances, the purchase of $120,000 in office furniture and an improper request to see files from a background check on his alleged relationships with reputed organized crime figures. 
 Since then, Trenton's police unions and some members of the city force have been in open revolt at what they contend are the misguided and politically motivated strong-arm tactics of the new leadership.
 ''I recognized that he was a pariah at the time,'' Mr. Palmer said. ''People said he was in the mob; that he's spent extravagant amounts of money on furniture; that he was going to get indicted. So I did my due diligence. I asked the people who were saying these things if he was really going to jail. They said, 'Well well ' I said, 'Fine, you didn't get along with him. But I know what he's accomplished in the past, and I've got a job for him to do here.' And he's been doing it.''
 In addition to local tensions in Trenton, cooperation between local and state law enforcement entities is not what it could be. Mr. Harvey, who tangled with Mr. Santiago and played a role in his departure from the state police, described his relationship with the police director as ''a work in progress.'' 
 Nor are all of the police convinced of the merits of the new routine. Officers involved with police unions -- who have been the most critical of the institutional changes since a referendum in 1999 ceded control of the department to the mayor -- suggested that many of the reforms were motivated more by politics and personal ambition than by a genuine desire for reform.
 ''They're running the department through intimidation rather than trying to lead by example,'' said Len Cipriano, president of Local 11 of the Policeman's Benevolent Association. ''It's not working. Some crime may be down -- minor thefts, stuff like that -- but shooting, homicides, aggressive assaults are on the upswing.''
 Some neighborhood residents say that while they have seen an increased effort to combat crime, they have also watched the situation on the streets grow worse.
 ''Crime is on the rise, you know?'' said Wayne Council, 50, a lifelong resident who spent much of his youth in and out of prison, and now has a business selling clothing from a van on Walnut Street, Stuyvesant Street and other locations he describes as ''the worst areas in the city.'' 
 ''I think the police are doing the best they can do with what they got,'' Mr. Council said. ''And they're definitely doing more than before. But now you get 10 kids coming out here, part of one of these gangs, and they're just running wild.''
 Mr. Council, who has been the victim of a gang attack, said that ''the best police can do is move them -- at least get them off the corner and go somewhere else.''
 ''But that's not a solution,'' he said. ''They can make whatever changes they want, but I'm going to wait and see before I say they're doing a good job. There's no solution until they can get these kids together and educate them. Otherwise, the problems will be the same.''

HEADLINE: High-Tech, High Stakes

BYLINE: By TERRY GOLWAY

DATELINE: BASKING RIDGE 

 BODY:
NOT so long ago, the former AT&T headquarters just off Interstate 287 was a symbol of modern, postwar New Jersey. The buildings were low-rise and sprawling. Parking was plentiful. And the mailing address was not a worn and gritty industrial city but a gleaming suburb in Somerset County.
 But slightly more than two years ago a shrunken and humbled AT&T sold the sprawling campus to Pharmacia, part of the pharmaceutical giant Pfizer, for $200 million. Soon afterward, however, Pfizer put the huge facility back on the market. 
 Today, vacant buildings and empty parking lots offer dreary testimony to a revolution in telecommunications brought about by deregulation, rapid changes in technology and the emergence of more nimble competitors, a revolution that has cost New Jersey tens of thousands of jobs in the last 15 years. AT&T itself may yet go the way of Bethlehem Steel, Pan Am and other ghosts of the 20th century. Only weeks ago, SBC of San Antonio, announced plans to acquire AT&T, based in Bedminster, for $16 billion.
 There is a possibility, however, that the future of telecommunications in New Jersey will soon pay tribute to its past by restoring jobs and purpose to this service-economy graveyard. Verizon Communications Inc. -- the nation's largest telephone company -- is considering putting a new operations center in Basking Ridge. 
 At stake are nearly 2,000 jobs that would be shifted from Verizon headquarters in New York. In addition, about 2,500 employees of Verizon Wireless, which is also based in Bedminster, could be moved to the campus here. But it is hardly a done deal. Indeed, Basking Ridge is just one of the sites under consideration, and not all of them are in New Jersey. Verizon is also being seriously courted by officials to move to northern Virginia. While Gov. Mark Warner's office has confirmed that it is in negotiations with Verizon, a spokeswoman for the Virginia governor, Ellen Qualls, declined to comment further.
 As recently as last week, acting Gov. Richard J. Codey tried to fend off the threat from Virginia by offering Verizon an economic incentive package amounting to $63.9 million if it agreed to locate its operations center in the state. 
 The state treasurer, John McCormac, announced the initiative -- the first official acknowledgment from Trenton that New Jersey was in the running for the Verizon relocation -- and a decision is expected within the next few weeks.
 Mr. McCormac, who is deeply involved in the talks with Verizon, emphasized that Mr. Codey was intent on keeping jobs and creating new ones. But according to some economic experts, a good deal more than several thousand Verizon jobs is at stake. If New Jersey, a capital of the old telecommunications world, can reinvent itself as a center in the new wireless world, other good-paying jobs will follow. 
 ''Wireless is the wave of the future,'' said Dr. Carl Van Horn, director of the Heldrich Center for Workforce Development at Rutgers University. ''It is extremely important for the state to be successful in this growing part of the telecommunications industry. Opportunities are shifting away from the copper line sector to the wireless side, and it would be important for us to have wireless headquartered here.''
 Verizon Wireless accounted for more than 40 percent of the parent's revenue in the final quarter of 2004, according to company figures. Revenue from the wireless component was just over $7 billion in the year's final three months, an increase of more than 22 percent over the same period in 2003. Over all, revenue for Verizon Wireless amounted to more than $27 billion last year, a $5 billion increase over 2003. Based in those figures, it is not a surprise that the Codey administration put together the second-largest incentive program ever offered by the state to keep Verizon Wireless in New Jersey and to attract the more than 1,700 jobs that will be moved out of Manhattan and into the new operations center.
 ''The stakes are very high,'' said Philip K. Beachem, president of New Jersey Alliance for Action, an Edison-based advocacy group of business leaders, labor organizers and academicians. ''In light of the state's budget situation,'' he said, referring to the $4 billion deficit this year, ''there is an economic incentive to go after Verizon aggressively. And I think the governor and treasurer are doing that.'' 
 Verizon only last week formally acknowledged that it was considering New Jersey and Virginia as potential sites for an operations center. Previously it had considered moving its full corporate headquarters out of New York, but decided instead to sell its current home in midtown and relocate employees to another office on West Street in downtown. ''We have 18,500 people in New York City, and that figure will remain consistent,'' said Peter Thonis, a Verizon spokesman. ''In addition, however, we plan to establish a new operations center at a new location. That will include leadership teams, business support, Verizon Wireless and other employees. We have not selected a site.'' 
 While Mr. Thonis would confirm only that New Jersey and Virginia were in the running, people close to the talks say the former AT&T facility in Basking Ridge is considered a tempting location. And a spokesman for Pfizer, which owns the 140-acre site, confirmed that it was for sale but declined to identify potential buyers.
 Working in New Jersey's favor, say those close to the talks, is the fact that Verizon Wireless is situated Bedminster. Moving 2,500 workers from there to Basking Ridge -- less than 10 miles away -- would not be nearly as complicated and costly as moving them to northern Virginia.
 If the Codey administration succeeds in luring Verizon, observers like Dr. Van Horn hope it will mark a new beginning for the state's telecommunications industry. The old, wired world represented by the AT&T facility in Basking Ridge is beyond frayed. ''We have lost more than any other state in terms of market share of the telecommunications pie,'' said Dr. Van Horn, noting that New Jersey was home to 6 percent of the nation's telecommunications jobs in 1990, but only 4 percent last year.
 Breaking down the numbers more, a study by Dr. Ken Dautrich, director of the Institute for Public Affairs at the University of Connecticut, showed that New Jersey shed 14,000 telecommunications jobs from 2001 to 2003 alone. But, offering hope, he found that while 10 percent of the state's telecommunications workers were employed by ''nonwired companies'' in 1990, that figure passed 36 percent last year.

HEADLINE: Teaching Students to Swim in the Online Sea

BYLINE: By GEOFFREY NUNBERG. 
Geoffrey Nunberg, a Stanford linguist, is heard on NPR's ''Fresh Air'' and is the author of ''Going Nucular'' (PublicAffairs, 2004).

 BODY:
INFORMATION literacy seems to be a phrase whose time has come. Last month, the Educational Testing Service announced that it had developed a test to measure students' ability to evaluate online material. That suggested an official recognition that the millions spent to wire schools and universities is of little use unless students know how to retrieve useful information from the oceans of sludge on the Web.
 Clearly, ''computer skills'' are not enough. A teacher of Scandinavian literature at Berkeley recently described how students used the Web to research a paper on the Vikings: ''They're Berkeley students, so, of course, they have the sense to restrict their searches to 'vikings NOT minnesota.' But they're perfectly willing to believe a Web site that describes early Viking settlements in Oklahoma.'' 
 That trusting nature is partly a legacy of the print age. If we tend to give the benefit of the doubt to the things we read in library books, it is because they have been screened twice: first by a publisher, who decided they were worth printing, and then by the librarian who acquired them or the professor who requested their purchase.
 The Web imposes no such filters, even as it allows users to examine subjects people would never have gone to a traditional library to research, like buying a printer or a cheap airline ticket. Many adolescents use the Internet to get information about issues they are reluctant to discuss with parents or teachers, like sexual behavior, sexual identity, drug use or depression and suicide.
 But there is a paradox in the way people think of the Web. Everyone is aware that it teems with rotten information, but most people feel confident that they can sort out the dross. In a survey released last month by the Pew Project on the Internet and American Life, 87 percent of search-engine users said they found what they were looking for all or most of the time.
 That level of confidence may not be justified, particularly when a search for information requires judging a Web site's credibility. According to the Pew survey, only 38 percent of search-engine users were aware of the difference between unpaid and sponsored search results, and only 18 percent could tell which was which.
 A 2002 study directed by BJ Fogg, a Stanford psychologist, found that people tend to judge the credibility of a Web site by its appearance, rather than by checking who put it up and why. But it is much easier to produce a professional-looking Web site than a credible-looking book. The BBC was recently duped by a fake Dow Chemical site into broadcasting an interview with an environmentalist posing as a company spokesman.
 Then, too, search engines make it all too easy to filter information in ways that reinforce pre-existing biases. A Google search on ''voting machine fraud,'' for example, will turn up popular Web pages that feature those words prominently, most of which will support the view that voting machines make election fraud easier; opposing sites won't tend to feature that language, so will be missed in the search. A researcher exploring the same topic in a library would be more likely to encounter diverse points of view. 
 Up to now, librarians have taken the lead in developing information literacy standards and curriculums. There's a certain paradox in that, because a lot of people assumed that the digital age would require neither libraries nor librarians. But today, students have only limited contact with librarians, particularly because they do most of their online information-seeking at home or in the dorm.
 More important, leaving information literacy to librarians alone suggests a failure to understand the scope of the problem.
 Part of it lies in the word ''literacy'' itself. No other language has a word that covers such a broad swath of territory, from reading and writing skills, to a familiarity with culture, to elementary competence in subjects like math or geography. To many, ''information literacy'' suggests a set of basic ABC's that can be consigned to Information 101.
 One can list some basic principles of information literacy, like ''Recognize an information need''; ''Evaluate sources critically''; and ''Check to see if the site sponsor is reputable.'' But those precepts are only of limited help with all that people now use online resources to do.
 Last fall, for example, I co-taught a graduate course on ''Information Quality'' at Berkeley's School of Information Management and Systems. The students were highly sophisticated about search engines and knew their way around the Web. 
 But even they had difficulty with exercises that involved evaluating information in unfamiliar areas, like using the Web to decide which online degree program to recommend to a friend.
 Still, given more time, those students would have known where to go for more accurate maps of the territory they were exploring. Unlike most students, they knew that ''what's out there'' doesn't end with what comes up on Google. University librarians complain that students tend to confine their online research to Web searches, ignoring other resources that the libraries have access to, like old newspaper archives, map collections and census data.
 No less important, the students in our course would have known to use an even more basic technique: asking the right person. E-mail turns the Web into a vast digital help desk; user groups are teeming with people who will gladly explain the finer points of espresso machines or the history of English slang. But most people rarely think to make use of them.
 In the end, then, instruction in information literacy will have to pervade every level of education and every course in the curriculum, from university historians' use of collections of online slave narratives to middle-school home economics teachers showing their students where to find reliable nutrition information on the Web.
 Even then, it is true, most people will fall back on perfunctory techniques for finding and evaluating information online. As Professor Fogg observes, people tend to be ''cognitive misers,'' relying on superficial cues whenever they can get away with it. 
 Only when confronting a question that is personally important -- a health problem, a major purchase -- are most people motivated to dig deeper. But that is reason enough to make sure that people have the skills they will need.

HEADLINE: A Golden Opportunity To Make Fiscal Sense

BYLINE: By Laura Mansnerus. 
Laura Mansnerus reports from Trenton for The New York Times.

 BODY:
A solution to New Jersey's all-but-intractable fiscal problem -- that is, the state keeps spending more money than it takes in -- is within reach, perhaps for the first time in years and the last time in years. 
 As a lame duck, Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey can propose some brave measures, like raising more taxes. Members of the Senate are not up for re-election until 2007. And while the whole General Assembly is up for re-election in November, that is still a long five months from June, with a lovely, long summer between. The whole crew could cut the Whitman tax cuts, sacrifice some pork and give up borrowing forever. 
 Almost no one thinks that is going to happen, though. The future of the Democratic Party is at stake here, and it is not in the mood to take risks.
 This is so despite the Democrats' lock on Trenton. The party is all but assured of the governor's office for the next five years, and probably nine. The Assembly is so packed with Democrats that they would have to make a huge effort to lose their majority. The Senate is theirs for the next three years -- and the next three budgets. 
 The immediate problem is that for the 2006 fiscal year, starting July 1, the state has about $4 billion less than it needs. The current budget, at $28 billion, was balanced with $2 billion in borrowing that the Supreme Court has since disapproved. A string of one-shot, revenue-raising schemes, like bonds financed by future revenue expected from the nationwide tobacco settlement, has exhausted the obvious desperation moves.
 Mr. Codey, who will deliver his proposed budget on March 1, has floated several ideas: turning over the New Jersey Turnpike to a private operator, taxing professional services and 401(k) retirement accounts and even raising the income tax rate on joint incomes over $150,000. 
 The proposed tax increases are encouraging to some Democrats who are not running for anything.
 Jon Shure, the president of New Jersey Policy Perspective, a liberal research group in Trenton, said he would extend the sales tax and raise the income tax, which seems less crazy since he led a successful campaign last year for the ''millionaire's tax'' on incomes over $500,000. Over the last decade, Mr. Shure said, the income tax cuts made by former Gov. Christie Whitman cost the state about $10 billion.
 The Republicans -- speaking of outsiders -- are already protesting any suggestion of any kind of tax increase. But the more difficult opposition might come from the Assembly, Democratic majority and all. 
 ''The Senate can be brave and philosophical and talk about the long term,'' said Senator John H. Adler, a Democrat, ''but in the Assembly they have to think about re-election.'' 
 And surely they are. In the last week the chairman of the Assembly Budget Committee, Louis Greenwald, said in several published reports that proposals to raise the income tax would go nowhere this year.
 As for the Democrats' enormous advantage in the Assembly, which does not seem to be in danger, Mr. Shure said, ''Tell them that.''
 ''They'll say, 'I have to run for re-election,'.'' he said. ''Well, can you run for re-election if you raise college tuition and everything else? The price you might pay for raising revenues may not be as high as the price you pay for not meeting the need.''
 Mr. Shure, sounding less optimistic by the second, said governors are always a problem, too, even in a cooperative economy. ''In good times, governors have plenty to spend but don't want to spend the political capital it takes to set things right,'' he said.
 Mr. Shure has reason to know. He was the press secretary for Gov. Jim Florio, Mrs. Whitman's predecessor, who was removed by the voters after pushing through a $2.8 billion tax increase. Reasonably or not, Democrats still talk about it. 
 Mr. Codey could be fairly heroic to his fellow Democrats, giving them cover with a public lament that the state can no longer afford the Whitman tax cuts. 
 But since he apparently plans to stay in politics -- as Senate president, no less -- Mr. Codey might not like to be lodged in the state's memory with Jim Florio.

HEADLINE: Social Isolation, Guns and a 'Culture of Suicide'

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD

DATELINE: STEVENSVILLE, Mont. 

 BODY:
Patrick Spaulding, 17, was the star of his basketball team, an honor student and one of the most popular boys in his class at Stevensville High School here in western Montana.
 Bill Tipps, 83, was devoted to his wife of 62 years, Louise, who had developed diabetes and who he feared would need to have her leg amputated. 
 Ron Malensek, 42, owned several small businesses, collected guns and called his wife ''Princess.'' 
 All three died of a single gunshot wound to the head in this valley below the snow-covered Bitterroot Mountains. All three pulled the trigger themselves. 
 Death by gunfire is typically thought of as an urban plague, fueled by crime, poverty and drugs.
 But rural America also has such an affliction. ''Americans in small towns and rural areas are just as likely to die from gunfire as Americans in major cities,'' said Charles Branas, an assistant professor of epidemiology at the University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine. ''The difference is in who does the shooting.''
 No matter the method, suicides occur at a higher rate in rural areas than in cities or suburbs, with the rate rising steadily the more rural the community. With homicides, the trend works in reverse, with higher rates in more urban areas.
 Researchers have long known the statistics, but new research illuminates the substantial role of firearms in suicide. 
 When Professor Branas examined data from the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, he found that the risk of dying by gunshot was the same in rural and urban areas from 1989 to 1999, findings that were published in The American Journal of Public Health. He has also concluded that in the most rural counties, the incidence of suicide with guns is greater than the incidence of murder with guns in major cities.
 Many of the cases in Stevensville and in other rural areas have common threads, professors and epidemiologists say.
 People who see themselves as rugged frontiersmen are often reluctant to reach out for help, particularly for mental health treatment. If they do, they may see a physician instead of a psychiatrist or another trained mental health expert.
 Suicide risk factors like depression, economic worries and alcohol use are, of course, prevalent in urban areas, said Dr. Alex Crosby, an epidemiologist in the National Center for Injury Prevention and Control at the Centers for Disease Control. But they are heightened in rural areas by social isolation, lack of mental health care and the easy availability of guns. 
 ''People say, 'How could people living in such beautiful places commit suicide?''' said Nels Sanddal, a psychologist in Bozeman, Mont., and president of the Critical Illness and Trauma Foundation, which works to prevent suicides. ''We have a culture of suicide.''

Surprise Over Statistics
 As far back as 1890, soon after Montana became a state, statistics from the Census Bureau showed that it had the highest suicide rate in the nation, Mr. Sanddal said.
 ''When you have seen other people exercise it as an option in a difficult situation, it becomes easier for you to exercise it as an option,'' he said. ''So now suicide is condoned or tolerated in Montana, even if people don't talk about it.''
 Stevensville is in Ravalli County, which has a suicide rate more than twice the national average. Since 1990, the county has had 103 suicides, more than three quarters of which involved a firearm. By comparison, there have been just 13 homicides in the county, whose population has swelled 44 percent in that time, to 36,000 people.
 The youngest to commit suicide in the county was 13 and the oldest was 92. Reflecting a national pattern, suicides rise sharply with age among men in the county. 
 The editor of The Ravalli Republic, the local daily newspaper, said that it is against the paper's policy to report on suicides and that he was unaware of a sizable number of incidents in the county. 
 When asked about the high suicide figures, Sheriff Chris Hoffman said, ''This shocks me,'' even though he is also the coroner and signs all death certificates. Since the 1890's, Sheriff Hoffman's family has raised cattle in the Bitterroot area, which Lewis and Clark traversed in 1805 and described as the most difficult part of their journey. 
 ''People here are not aware of all the suicides,'' he said. ''It's not something people here talk about.''
 Professor Branas said he encountered similar surprise when he conducted field studies in rural counties in Iowa, Ohio and Pennsylvania. 
 Most families of those who committed suicide around Stevensville in the last year declined to be interviewed. But relatives and friends of several people who died in previous years agreed, often reluctantly, to talk. 
 Mary Lee Rush, whose son committed suicide at 29 and who lives in Grantsdale, an unincorporated town in Ravalli County, said: ''People here are very rural. They do for themselves. They won't go for help.'' 
 Suicide, she said, ''is an acceptable way of dying if you feel desolate or you can't handle things anymore.''

A Young Life Ended
 Patrick Spaulding, a 6-foot-4-inch senior, was the leading scorer on his high school basketball team and had set a school record with 28 rebounds in a single game. ''He lived for basketball,'' said his mother, Paulette Spaulding, who lives in the family house with her husband about five miles outside Stevensville. Patrick was consistently on the honor roll.
 On a Friday night in January 1997, Patrick went out and drank a few beers, his friends said, and on the way home apparently fell asleep at the wheel, entangling his pickup truck in barbed wire. A sheriff's deputy gave Patrick a citation for illegal possession of alcohol.
 ''Under school rules, that would have meant he would be suspended from the team for the rest of the season,'' his mother said. ''He was such a perfectionist, always harder on himself than on anyone else, he felt he had let his family and teammates down.'' He did not discuss the situation with his parents. The next morning, the day of a big game, alone in his bedroom, Patrick shot himself.
 ''Teenagers don't live for tomorrow, they live for today,'' Mrs. Spaulding said.
 At Stevensville High School, the guidance counselor, Linda Mullan, was concerned about how other students would respond to Patrick's death and was worried about the possibility of copycats. Many students own guns and hunt, often starting in junior high school. ''Guns and hunting are a rite of passage in Montana,'' Ms. Mullan said.
 Two seniors in the same class as Patrick were so distraught by his death that they turned down appointments to the Air Force Academy, preferring to concentrate on trying to heal the wounds of grief among their classmates and prevent any further tragedy, Ms. Mullan said.
 A few families of those who have taken their own lives have begun organizing themselves to better understand what happened. Pat Kendall, whose son, Josh, shot himself in the Blue Mountains in 2000, when he was 23, has opened a resource center with a lending library in a small house in Missoula, at the northern end of the valley. She has also helped get the Missoula County Health Department to start a suicide prevention program, the first of its kind in the area.
 What Mrs. Kendall has come to believe is that her son probably had bipolar disorder. When he finally went to a doctor, not long before he killed himself, the doctor, who was not a trained psychiatrist, prescribed the antidepressant Prozac. But Prozac can make mood swings worse for some people with bipolar disorder. Mrs. Kendall believes that in a region with few mental health resources, Josh's problem was mistaken for depression.

'A Mercy Killing'
 Bill Tipps and his wife, Louise, moved to Stevensville from a suburb of Las Vegas to be close to their adult son, Dennis Tipps, who was the high school football coach and onetime police chief. 
 Dennis Tipps found a site for a home for his parents nearby in an area of small farms and new houses. One of his sons, Dennis Jr., a contractor, built them a simple ranch-style home. 
 But Bill Tipps grew depressed. ''My dad hated the cold and the winter,'' Dennis Tipps said.
 He was also becoming increasingly concerned about the health of his wife, who was 80. She had undergone several heart surgeries, and the local doctor said her toes might have to be amputated because of diabetes.
 Dennis Tipps now surmises that when the doctor pointed with a sweeping gesture to Louise Tipps's foot, and then her knee and hip, Bill Tipps assumed the doctor was suggesting that his wife's leg would also have to be taken off. 
 His father hated doctors and would not seek their advice, Dennis Tipps said. So his father never clarified his wife's prognosis or sought help for his apparent depression.
 His father ''never displayed his emotions,'' Dennis Tipps said. ''He kept everything inside, and he was very stubborn. He wouldn't change his mind.'' 
 One morning in September 1999, at 8:05 a.m., Bill Tipps called his son at his home. 
 ''I just shot and killed your mother so they can't take her leg off,'' said the elder Mr. Tipps, who was 83. ''Now I'm going to shoot myself.''
 Dennis Tipps jumped in his truck, and as he approached his parents' house, he heard what he thought was his engine backfiring. It was his father shooting himself.
 ''In my dad's mind, this was a mercy killing,'' Dennis Tipps said. ''He would never leave her side. He thought he was doing the right thing, but he overreacted.''

'He Just Quit'
 Debbie Miller describes the gentle side of her husband, Ron Malensek. ''He called me Princess and treated me like a princess,'' she said. 
 But Mr. Malensek had been diagnosed with depression as a child, she said. 
 In early 2000, he called all his friends, told them goodbye and then tried to commit suicide by overdosing on pills. He survived, and she urged him to see a doctor, who prescribed Prozac.
 In the summer of 2003, Mr. Malensek stopped taking the medication. 
 Mr. Malensek had always worked seven days a week at various jobs: he had owned two bars, a gas station and a bingo parlor, and then had a business installing rain gutters. That summer, he started neglecting customers who called for estimates, Ms. Miller said. He became angry and could not sleep, and he had no energy, she said. It was as if ''he just quit,'' said Ms. Miller, a speech therapist at Stevensville High School.
 On Aug. 5 last year, they went to a favorite bar, the Rustic Hut, in the town of Florence. It was the anniversary of his father's death. 
 When Ms. Miller left to go home, her husband stayed at the bar. Then he walked out back, retrieved a handgun that he had stashed there earlier, and shot himself.
 After his death, Ms. Miller discovered that he had not shared other pressures with her. 
 ''It turned out there were a lot of financial issues I didn't know about,'' she said. Bill collectors bombarded her and repossessed his pickup truck. She had to sell his business.
 She also learned that he was a ''gun freak,'' she said. ''I'm still finding guns he had stashed all over the house.''
 Ms. Miller does not know the statistics about rural suicides, but she knows enough. Her father and her first husband also killed themselves.

HEADLINE: It's Not Too Late To Save

BYLINE: By JAN M. ROSEN

 BODY:
HEY, big spender. Here's a tax break for you: Beginning with 2004 tax returns, people who itemize their deductions may choose to deduct state and local sales taxes instead of state and local income taxes.
 In adding that provision, Congress clearly gave a break to residents of the seven states that have no income tax: Alaska, Florida, Nevada, South Dakota, Texas, Washington and Wyoming. Residents of the other 43 states can already deduct state and local income taxes, but in some cases, even in high-tax states like New York and California, they may be ahead by deducting sales taxes.
 People who have bought big-ticket items like cars or boats are one possible example, according to Neil Becourtney, a tax partner in the accounting firm of J.H. Cohn in Roseland, N.J. Another may be an older couple with an income, say, of $100,000, much of it from tax-exempt municipal bonds and pensions subject to state tax breaks. 
 The provision was included in the American Jobs Creation Act of 2004, which was enacted in October, and the Internal Revenue Service has published tables of sales taxes for each state in its new Publication 600, available at www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/p600.pdf. A worksheet for adding local sales taxes to the state sales taxes is included.
 ''I mailed the publication to about a dozen Florida clients,'' Mr. Becourtney said. ''It's win-win; you can only come out ahead. For many taxpayers it will lower 2004 federal income taxes.''
 Following are other considerations for taxpayers this tax season:

THE ALTERNATIVE MINIMUM TAX -- The ever-growing number of people subject to the alternative minimum tax will not benefit from the sales tax deduction. Under that tax, no deductions for state and local taxes -- and that includes property taxes -- are allowed.
 Some 2.4 million individual tax returns for 2003 had an A.M.T. liability, according to the I.R.S, up from 1.9 million a year earlier, and by 2010 the number is expected to surge to 35 million. Many reasons, as varied as exercising incentive stock options and claiming tax credits can lead to an A.M.T. liability. In the New York metropolitan area, where both state income taxes and suburban real estate taxes are relatively high, those deductions could snare a high percentage of taxpayers. As a result, taxpayers should be sure to calculate their liabilities under both the regular and alternative systems, Mr. Becourtney said. 
 ''It's better than having the I.R.S. send you a computer notice'' demanding an additional tax payment plus interest, he said. ''It's nondeductible consumer interest, adding insult to injury.''
 Bernard S. Kent, of Detroit, who is the partner in charge of personal financial services for PricewaterhouseCoopers in the Midwest, said, ''There are not many things you can do retroactively,'' if you are liable for the alternative tax. But people may want to analyze whether they are likely to be permanently liable for it, as they may be if they live where state and local taxes are high. If so, he said, ''Do you want to move? Do you want to rent?'' 
 Taxpayers who are likely to have future A.M.T. liabilities and who own municipal bonds should ask their brokers whether their bonds are subject to the alternative tax, Mr. Kent said, and they should consider paying off home equity loans that are being used for home improvement because they are not deductible under the A.M.T.

CHARITABLE CONTRIBUTIONS -- Donations to charity are deductible under both the regular tax system and the A.M.T. Mr. Kent offered two tips for protecting those deductions.
 People who make large donations of personal property like artwork or collectibles worth more than $5,000 must have a professional appraisal and must fill out Form 8283, he said. If the value exceeds $500,000, he added, they should attach the appraisal to the return. 
 For any donation of $250 or more, taxpayers must have an acknowledgment letter from the charity in their files before the due date of the return. If taxpayers made contributions toward tsunami relief in January 2005, they have the option of deducting them on their 2004 returns. But if they do not receive the acknowledgment letter in time, Mr. Kent said, it would be prudent to file for an extension to file.

HEALTH SAVINGS ACCOUNTS -- These relatively new accounts are ''available to everyone who has high-deductible health insurance'' and is not covered by Medicare or another health insurance plan, said Donna LeValley, a tax lawyer and contributing editor to ''J.K. Lasser's Your Income Tax 2005.''
 Because contributions are deductible, even for people who do not itemize, and earnings accumulate tax-free and distributions for medical care are tax-free, they are ''great accounts to look into,'' she said. The law defines high deductible as at least $1,000.
 Eligible people have until April 15 this year to contribute to a health savings account for 2004. Under a transition rule for 2004, when the accounts began, account holders may be reimbursed for eligible expenses incurred last year even before the account was set up. The deduction is limited to the annual deductible on the qualifying health plan and is capped at $2,600 for an individual or $5,150 for a family. Taxpayers who are 55 or older can deduct an additional $500. The plans are explained in I.R.S. Publication 969, at www.irs.gov/publications/p969/ar01.html.

SMALL-BUSINESS OWNERS -- People who own small businesses, including sole proprietors who file a Schedule C with their tax return, may be able to claim big upfront deductions for business expenses for two more years. The tax break was due to expire in 2005, but it has been extended to 2007, thanks to provisions in the 2004 jobs creation act. The limit for this deduction on 2004 returns is $102,000; for this year and future years, it will be adjusted for inflation. ''It is definitely good to plan and make the big purchase this year or next,'' Ms. LeValley said.
 The law tightened up a loophole that was popular with business owners. Many bought sport utility vehicles weighing over 6,000 pounds and claimed an immediate deduction, and they can still do so on 2004 returns for purchases made before Oct. 22, 2004. After that, the first-year write-off is limited to $25,000.
 People who are just starting a business also get two nice breaks under the new law, Ms. LeValley said. They can choose to deduct upfront up to $5,000 of business start-up costs and organizational costs of corporations and partnerships paid or incurred after Oct. 22, 2004, instead of amortizing them. ''It flows through to the personal return,'' she said. ''It's terrific because the first year is the most difficult year.''

INVESTMENTS -- Laws in recent years have trimmed taxes on most investment income, opening new opportunities for future saving, too. Most dividends on stocks and long-term capital gains are taxed at 15 percent for taxpayers in the upper brackets and at 5 percent for those in the 10 percent and 15 percent brackets on earned income.
 Joanne E. Johnson, a lawyer who is a managing director in the wealth advisory group at J.P. Morgan Private Bank in New York, recommended that as taxpayers receive their 2004 tax records they review their portfolios with an eye toward reducing risk and concentrated positions. ''Fifteen percent is what I consider cheap,'' she said. ''It's a lovely opportunity to rebalance your portfolio, to take some returns and put the money to work somewhere else.''
