HEADLINE: Rift Deepens as Professors At Harvard See Transcript

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 18 

 BODY:
A mood of uncertainty settled over Harvard University on Friday in the aftermath of President Lawrence H. Summers's release of the transcript of his contentious remarks last month about the shortage of women in the sciences and engineering.
 Many people were parsing and debating the often dense and rambling 7,000-word transcript, a long-awaited document that quickly became a must-read on campus. 
 A group of professors and students was collecting names on letters supporting Dr. Summers. Another group of professors, who had criticized Dr. Summers's leadership style at a tense faculty meeting on Tuesday, was continuing to discuss the matter. 
 Scholars normally immersed in research and teaching were preoccupied with questions about the leadership of the university, to which many of them have devoted their adult lives.
 ''My sense of the mood among key faculty is that they're deeply, deeply distressed about the way this entire thing is tearing the university apart, the Faculty of Arts and Sciences in particular,'' said Theda Skocpol, a government professor who spoke out against Dr. Summers at the meeting. ''And I share that distress.''
 Daniel Laibson and Claudia Goldin, both economics professors, were among those leading the effort to collect the signatures of full professors throughout the university on a letter endorsing Dr. Summers's leadership.
 ''Everyone has a viewpoint,'' Professor Laibson said. ''At this moment there's a great deal of intensity. All of us care passionately about this university''
 Professor Laibson estimated that 160 professors had signed the letter so far, with many of them representing the sciences, he said. Dr. Summers has made the sciences a major focus of his administration.
 An emergency meeting of the Faculty of Arts and Sciences, which is considered the heart of the university, has been scheduled for Tuesday to continue the discussion of Dr. Summers's leadership. 
 Despite talk of a no-confidence vote, professors said such a vote would be highly unlikely at the meeting because so many had signed up to speak. As a practical matter, they said, the earliest date for such a vote would be March 15, at the regular meeting of the Faculty of Arts and Sciences. 
 Despite the concerns voiced at last Tuesday's meeting about what some faculty members described as Dr. Summers's intimidating style, there has been no organized demand for his resignation. On Thursday, James Houghton, a senior member of the Harvard Corporation, which appointed the president and is the only body that can remove him, affirmed the corporation's support for Dr. Summers, saying he had ''brought energetic leadership to an unusually complex and demanding job.'' 
 The letter of support circulating among the faculty emphasizes Dr. Summers's strengths and the achievements of his three-and-a-half-year administration. ''He devotes himself to finding and implementing policies that enrich the minds of Harvard's students and extend the frontiers of human understanding,'' it reads in part.
 The letter also acknowledges that Dr. Summers ''has made mistakes,'' and adds, ''We agree that his personal interactions sometimes feel confrontational.''
 The debate over Dr. Summers's leadership has now extended to the professional schools. At the medical school, Dr. Nicholas A. Christakis, a physician who is a professor of health care policy, said he spent a day studying Dr. Summers's remarks and mulling over the letter of support before signing it.
 ''I'm sure hundreds of hours of expensive faculty time have been spent in the last two days in deciding what to do about this matter,'' Dr. Christakis said.
 He added that he believed that Dr. Summers had been vilified and said he did not think Dr. Summers's remarks about women were ''unreasonable.''
 Eric Chivian, an assistant clinical professor of psychiatry at the medical school who shared in the 1985 Nobel Peace Prize, said he did not sign the letter. Instead, Dr. Chivian said, he reluctantly wrote his own letter to the Harvard Corporation.
 The letter criticizes what Dr. Chivian calls Dr. Summers's pattern of insensitive, divisive comments and describes reports from numerous faculty members of ''Dr. Summers' reputation for abusing his position of power and for vindictiveness towards those who disagree with him.''
 Noting that he is an alumnus of both the college and the medical school, Dr. Chivian wrote that the recent remarks about women ''should finally convince the corporation that President Summers has brought, and will continue to bring, embarrassment and dishonor to the university.'' 
 He also wrote that many alumni, himself included, ''will no longer contribute money to the university as long as he is its president.''
 Dr. Chivian said in an interview that ''it should be Harvard's extraordinary accomplishments in medicine, science, the humanities and in other disciplines that are daily front page news, not its crisis of governance, brought on by Lawrence Summer's failure of leadership.'' 
 ''For the good of the university,'' he added, ''it is time for him to resign.''
 For now, the campus is anticipating Tuesday's meeting. So many professors have expressed an interest in attending that the meeting has been moved to a larger room. 

CORRECTION-DATE: February 21, 2005

 CORRECTION:
An article on Saturday about the divisions at Harvard over remarks by its president, Lawrence H. Summers, misstated the given name of an economics professor who is seeking signatures on a letter supporting Dr. Summers. He is David Laibson, not Daniel.

HEADLINE: Shares Finish Mixed as Concern About Inflation Rises

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
A sharp rise in wholesale prices intensified fears about inflation, sending stocks to a mixed finish yesterday as bond prices fell. 
 Blue-chip stocks got a late lift from the pharmaceutical sector, but the major indexes finished the week with losses.
 Investors were surprised as a Labor Department report showed wholesale prices rising at the fastest rate in six years. While the Producer Price Index rose just 0.3 percent in January, a drop in oil and food prices kept that figure artificially low. With oil and food removed, the core figure rose 0.8 percent, a hefty increase that could signal higher consumer prices down the road. 
 ''Inflation-sensitive stocks are doing well, but that's about it,'' said Brian Pears, head equity trader at Victory Capital Management in Cleveland. ''There's not a lot of reason for people to make bets on too many other sectors.''
 But the Dow Jones industrials and large-cap stocks rose in late trading as federal regulators approved the continued marketing of painkillers from Merck and Pfizer, saying the benefits for patients outweighed increased risks of heart attack and strokes.
 The Dow rose 30.96 points, or 0.29 percent, to 10,785.22. The Dow is once again up for the year to date, but by just 2.21 points, or 0.02 percent.
 The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was up 0.84 point, or 0.07 percent, at 1,201.59, while the technology-focused Nasdaq composite index lost 2.72 points, or 0.13 percent, to 2,058.62.
 Inflation concerns kept the markets from substantially surpassing their December 2004 highs this week. Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, while giving lawmakers a bullish assessment of the economy, warned that higher prices could become an issue.
 For the week, the Dow fell 0.1 percent, the S.&P. 500 was down 0.34 percent and the Nasdaq dropped 0.87 percent.
 A rise in oil prices also pressured stocks. A barrel of light crude was quoted at $48.35, up 81 cents, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
 A muddled trading session turned higher thanks to the Dow's pharmaceutical components. Merck surged $3.76, or 13 percent, to $32.61 after a Food and Drug Administration advisory panel voted narrowly to allow Merck to continue marketing the arthritis drug Vioxx in the United States. The company voluntarily pulled Vioxx last year after it was found to carry an increased risk of heart attack and stroke.
 The advisory panel also ruled that two of Pfizer's pain relievers, Bextra and Celebrex, can remain on the market despite studies that questioned the safety of the drugs, which are chemically related to Vioxx. Pfizer gained $1.74, to $26.80.
 A fresh round of merger news also helped investors overcome the economic data. Qwest Communications International was up 11 cents, at $3.95, after the company said it would renew and possibly raise its bid for MCI, hoping to break a $6.7 billion deal by MCI and Verizon Communications. MCI rose $1.65, to $22.31, while Verizon slipped 37 cents, to $35.31.
 Ending what appeared to be an impasse, Federated Department Stores is again discussing a takeover bid for May Department Stores, The Wall Street Journal reported. The two sides are getting closer on a final price per share, the paper said. Federated lost 65 cents, to $56.72, while May added $1.93, to $33.45.
 In the bond market, the 10-year Treasury note fell 21/32, to 97 28/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 4.26 percent from 4.18 percent on Thursday.

HEADLINE: Japan Said to Support U.S. on Security of Taiwan

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 

 BODY:
Senior Japanese officials, in meetings here on Saturday, plan to assure their American counterparts that Japan shares a common concern about the future security of Taiwan, administration officials and a foreign diplomat said Friday.
 While Japan is not expected to make specific offers of military or logistical aid in the event China attacks Taiwan, officials said, it is increasingly concerned about the growing political and military might of China, which considers Taiwan a province and continually threatens the island.
 With its new assurance, officials said, Japan is moving closer to the American point of view: that the status quo between China and Taiwan should be maintained. 
 Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, speaking to reporters on Friday, said the United States and Japan shared the goal of maintaining peace between China and Taiwan. 
 ''The United States and Japan ''enjoy very deep and broad relations in an alliance to try and help bring and maintain peace and stability'' in the region, she said.
 She and Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld are to meet with the Japanese foreign minister, Nobutaka Machimura, and the Defense Agency director general, Yoshinori Ono, on Saturday. The primary topic is expected to be efforts to coax North Korea to return to talks on ending its nuclear weapons program.
 But an administration official said the United States and Japan would also issue a joint statement confirming a ''common strategic direction'' on policies toward Taiwan, China and other regional issues. On Taiwan, the statement will ''encourage the peaceful resolution'' of the Taiwan Strait dialogue, the administration official said. This would be the first time that Japan joined the United States in voicing public concern over China's growing military buildup in the area.
 A senior foreign diplomat said that has been Japan's policy for many years, even though it has not been stated in a public manner. The United States and Japan maintain complex and conflicted relationships with the Chinese. Both have valuable economic relationships with China. Last year, China replaced the United States as Japan's largest trading partner. China is an important trading partner for the United States, too. On Friday, the State Department announced that the Export-Import Bank of the United States had made a preliminary commitment to lend China $5 billion to build four nuclear power plants in Zhejiang and Yangjiang Provinces. 
 At the same time, however, the United States has had angry exchanges with China in the last few days. On Wednesday, Porter J. Goss, the director of central intelligence, issued a stern warning about China's growing military prowess. 
 ''Beijing's military modernization and military buildup could tilt the balance of power in the Taiwan Strait,'' he told the Senate Armed Services Committee, adding, ''Improved Chinese capabilities threaten United States forces in the region.''
 And on Thursday, Mr. Rumsfeld said the United States was concerned about the expansion of the Chinese Navy.
 In response, the Chinese Foreign Ministry, in a statement on Friday, angrily denounced those remarks, saying, ''The United States has severely interfered with Chinese internal affairs and sent a false signal to the advocates of Taiwan independence.''

HEADLINE: M.T.A. Bidding Stance Shows How Little Help Mayor Is Getting From the Governor

BYLINE: By JIM RUTENBERG and CHARLES V. BAGLI

 BODY:
A few weeks ago, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's relentless drive for a stadium for the Jets and the 2012 Olympics over the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's West Side railyards seemed to be inching toward the finish line.
 But the authority's agreement to consider a last-minute, rival bid for the development rights from Cablevision and any other bidders was another stark reminder of how little help Mr. Bloomberg is getting this election year from his counterpart in Albany, Gov. George E. Pataki, a fellow Republican. 
 Mr. Bloomberg was also stung by Mr. Pataki's failure, in the budget he released in January, to provide anywhere near the amount of money the mayor was seeking for school rebuilding projects and other educational aid. The mayor's Democratic mayoral opponents portrayed that as a slap in the face.
 The move by the M.T.A. to open the land to other bidders is coming across as, at the very least, benign neglect by Mr. Pataki, who appointed the authority's chairman, Peter S. Kalikow, and controls the authority's board.
 By inviting other bids, the authority raised serious questions about whether the stadium would ever be built. The invitation came just as the search team for the International Olympic Committee was preparing to visit New York to gauge whether the city is the best choice for the 2012 Games. 
 The increasingly pitched battle over a sports venue, viewed as crucial to the Olympics, threatens to become an embarrassing backdrop to the visit. 
 Press officers for Mr. Bloomberg and Mr. Pataki say that their relationship is solid and that they are of one mind about the stadium and the Olympics. 
 But tensions seemed to have risen between the state and the city the day that Cablevision offered two weeks ago to pay $600 million for the stadium site, hundreds of millions more than the Jets offered. Cablevision has been fighting the project because it says a West Side stadium will harm its venue, Madison Square Garden, by drawing away business.
 Agitated city officials, led by the deputy mayor for economic development and rebuilding, Daniel L. Doctoroff, called Mr. Kalikow that Friday and lobbied him to dismiss the bid -- which they have derided as an act of sabotage -- out of hand, according to several people familiar with the conversation, all of whom spoke on condition of anonymity.
 Mr. Doctoroff and the deputy mayor for operations, Marc V. Shaw, a former top official at the M.T.A., argued that the authority was within its rights to dismiss the bid because it had a memorandum of understanding with the Jets, these people said. 
 That memo of understanding had laid out a plan to have the stadium approved by last November. Construction was to begin in June, well before the July 6 Olympic Committee meeting at which it is decided whether New York or any of the other five cities in the running -- among them Paris and London -- will get the Games.
 An executive who knows both Mr. Doctoroff and Mr. Kalikow said the telephone call never devolved into anything near the standoff several months ago when they were discussing the value of the air rights of another part of the yards (That dispute, the executive said, ended with Mr. Kalikow storming out of the meeting room after stern words from Mr. Doctoroff and had set the tone for an overall tense relationship since.) 
 Mr. Kalikow and Mr. Doctoroff did not respond to requests for comment.
 Neither a spokesman for the mayor, Edward Skyler, nor a spokesman for the governor, David Catalfamo, would comment on what happened during a phone conversation between Mr. Bloomberg and Mr. Pataki after Cablevision made its offer.
 Either way, Mr. Pataki clearly sided with Mr. Kalikow's decision to open up the bidding for the site. Mr. Pataki said on Thursday that he would continue to ''push for'' the stadium but added that the authority had ''a fiduciary obligation to look and see if there are offered proposals that might be more in the public interest.''
 A state official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, added that Mr. Pataki believed he had no choice but to side with Mr. Kalikow. ''We believe that a process that is unassailable will ultimately result in the appropriate decision,'' this official said. ''The worst thing for the proponents of the West Side would be for the M.T.A. to rush to judgment, leaving them open to litigation that could delay the project for years."
 For his part, Mr. Skyler said, ''We have faith that through the process the M.T.A. has set up the best proposal will win and that the sports and convention center is the best proposal for the M.T.A. and the best proposal for the city.''
 Mr. Pataki's aides are clearly most concerned by the appearance that he is somehow undercutting the mayor's bid for the Olympics -- and his bid for a second term.
 The state official argued that Mr. Pataki had frequently voiced his backing for the stadium -- a pet project of the mayor, not the governor -- at no small risk to himself. ''Some critics of the governor's support of the mayor's priorities such as the West Side, or the Olympic bid, don't appreciate that the state is facing its own challenges,'' the official said.
 To underscore how supportive he was of the bid, aides to the governor noted on Friday that he was cutting short a vacation to the Dominican Republic to attend at least two events related to the Olympic Committee visit, both with the mayor. 
 Yet Mr. Pataki will not be attending a private dinner the mayor is having for the search committee members at his town house on Wednesday night. He will instead attend a rival Olympics-related event, the 25th anniversary celebration of the 1980 Winter Games in Lake Placid.

HEADLINE: Time Warner Stops Granting Stock Options To Most of Staff

BYLINE: By ERIC DASH

 BODY:
Time Warner said yesterday that it would no longer grant stock options to most employees, citing new accounting rules.
 The decision comes at a time when a number of companies that happily doled out options to employees during the last market boom are reining in their use. With the stock market weak, options no longer have much of a cachet for many employees. Some companies -- most notably Microsoft -- have sought other ways to link equity pay with performance. In 2003, Microsoft announced that it would award stock instead of granting stock options. 
 About half a dozen other companies, including Aetna and Charles Schwab, have either eliminated or significantly cut back on options for their rank and file in the last year, according to the National Center for Employee Ownership, an independent research group in Oakland, Calif.
 ''More and more companies today are no longer offering stock options to all employees,'' Ann Moore, the chief executive of Time Inc., and Norman Pearlstine, the editor in chief, said in a memo to employees of the Time unit. Most of the parent company's 80,000 employees will no longer receive stock options, a company spokeswoman said.
 Some workers, however, will continue to get stock options based on their job responsibilities and industry practice. The spokeswoman declined to describe how the decision would affect top executives or what would be the split among AOL workers, in the technology sector where stock option awards remain common, and the Time Warner journalists and entertainment employees. 
 The stock option grants will not be replaced with other forms of equity, the company said. Salaries and benefits will largely stay the same. 
 In the memo, Ms. Moore and Mr. Pearlstine suggested that the decision was made in response to pressure from investors and recent changes in accounting rules. New Securities and Exchange Commission rules, which require shareholders to approve option plans, have limited the pool of options. So have concerns about the way options can dilute earnings per share. 
 New financial reporting standards, the memo added, which will require companies to treat stock options as expenses, ''make it prohibitively expensive'' to continue the practice for all employees.
 Several corporate governance experts questioned that reasoning. Time Warner workers held 650 million stock options at the end of 2003, worth about $6.5 billion, according to regulatory filings.
 ''Either they were doing something all these years that made no economic sense,'' said Gregory P. Taxin, the chief executive of Glass Lewis & Company, an institutional advisory firm in San Francisco, ''or they are ending an economically viable program because of a requirement to disclose it.''
 ''Neither of those is a happy outcome for shareholders,'' he said. ''Either way, it causes you concern about the judgment of the board.''
 A number of companies are restricting options. ''Companies manage what they measure, and for the first time, we are going to have to measure the real cost of these options,'' said Lynn E. Turner, a former S.E.C. chief accountant who now oversees research at Glass Lewis. ''And the result is that companies are going to have to quit giving away the store.''
 But Ira Kay, a compensation consultant for Watson Wyatt Worldwide, said that dispensing with broad-based stock option plans could be a sign of a disturbing trend. ''The number of overall options is coming down, more slowly at the top and more rapidly at the bottom,'' he said. 
 Companies, meanwhile, are substituting other stock plans for stock options, frequently with lower net accounting costs or a reduction in the number of employees eligible, he noted. ''I am worried that reducing eligibility could create morale and productivity problems at some companies because historically, even though executives were well-paid, since many employees shared in the stock gains, there appeared to be very little resentment.''
 In addition to the companies that have dropped options programs, Delphi, Eastman Kodak and AstraZeneca plan to cut back on the options they distribute to regular employees, said Corey Rosen, the executive director of the National Center for Employee Ownership. Last year, Citigroup ended its renewable stock option plan, and like Cisco Systems, reduced the life span of the options it awarded to cut compensation costs. 
 Based on his research and industry survey data, Mr. Rosen estimated that at least 40 percent of publicly traded companies with stock option plans are reconsidering them and as many as a third may discontinue them in the next few years.
 But despite the talk about accounting expenses, Mr. Rosen suggested that most companies with broad-based stock option plans, about 17 percent of publicly traded companies, would keep them. ''Companies that are more committed to this, like Starbucks, Southwest Airlines, Whole Foods, will hold on to their programs,'' he said. ''And some companies, not nearly as much as anybody predicted, will change the form of the equity but they will still give everybody equity. When it actually came down to telling people, you are not going to get what you used to get, it's very difficult to do.''
 Most of the retrenchment may come from companies like Time Warner, which had a profit-sharing program before the AOL merger in 2001 and where a commitment to broad-based stock options was never strong in some divisions. 
 Employees at Time Inc. in New York said the development was expected in a climate of cost-cutting. Expense accounts are now closely scrutinized, the lavish holiday parties have been eliminated and even the magazines are now distributed in the lobby, not to employees' desks. 
 Time Inc. employees contacted yesterday shrugged off the loss of the options program. After all, the vast majority of stock options awarded over the last few years now have little or no market value.

HEADLINE: N.H.L. Labor Dispute Brings Painful Memories of 1994

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

DATELINE: FORT MYERS, Fla. 

 BODY:
NOT that we need another sports poll, but this one would be intriguing. Which is a greater blow to the country, its sports fabric and its sports fans: cancellation of the 1994 World Series or cancellation of the 2004-5 National Hockey League season? 
 When Gary Bettman announced Wednesday that he was canceling the season because of the labor dispute that prompted the N.H.L. to lock out its players, it was reminiscent of Bud Selig's announcement on Sept. 14, 1994, that he was canceling the remainder of the baseball season, the playoffs and the World Series because of a labor dispute that prompted the players to strike on Aug. 12.
 For baseball, it was the first time the World Series was not played since 1904. For the N.H.L., if the effort to save the season fails, it will be the first time since 1919 that there will be no Stanley Cup playoffs. 
 To digress for a moment, if you're looking for a link between that season and this, it's the Boston Red Sox. The Red Sox won the World Series in 1918 and, 86 years later, they won it again last October.
 Enough digression.
 ''I don't think I've ever had a more painful year in my life than 1994,'' Selig said. ''It was very sad and a very difficult year, so I have a great compassion for certainly Gary Bettman and all the people involved. Sports, like everything else in life, have changed. The economics have changed. Sometimes in confronting change we run into a lot of pain.''
 At the core of both cancellations was an effort by the owners to get a payroll cap linked to revenue. Baseball and hockey are the two sports that don't have payroll caps.
 Donald Fehr, head of the baseball union, said Bettman's announcement vividly reminded him of Selig's announcement. 
 ''As I watched the announcement being made, it brought back lots of memories from '94,'' he said. ''You just wish it didn't have to be this way. It seems like a long time ago in one respect, but memory seems very fresh when you see this happen.''
 Selig recalled that Jackie Autry, who was operating the Angels, ''begged me not to make the announcement; others said don't do that. But we were getting a lot of heat from people who wanted answers.
 ''The players were gone and I was getting calls from managers and general managers saying they're gone; you can't resume the season. At that point, I felt I owed it to the networks and the sponsors. The clubs needed to know. We were not having any discussions. We all knew we were going nowhere.''
 Although the similarity between the disputes figured to continue, one difference has developed. After Selig canceled the World Series, the labor representatives for the owners and the players didn't meet for 39 days, until Oct. 19.
 In the current dispute, the N.H.L and union representatives met again yesterday, although the talks broke off once again. 
 What remains to be seen is the direction the hockey talks now take. Obviously, the two sides must reach agreement to have a 2004-5 season. But if the two sides remain entrenched in their positions -- the league wanting a payroll cap, the union adamantly opposed to it -- N.H.L. officials could declare an impasse and unilaterally impose new work rules.
 That is what the baseball owners did in December 1994, but that was their mistake. The union went to the National Labor Relations Board, which agreed with the union's position that the owners should not be allowed to impose new work rules. 
 The board sought an injunction in federal court, and the union said the players would end their strike and return to work if the board got it. The board did. 
 Judge Sonia Sotomayor, who has probably not received enough credit for saving baseball -- though that was not what she set out to do -- ordered owners to restore the work rules that were in the expired agreement, and the players ended their strike.
 Before the hockey union accepted the concept of a payroll cap, though not linked to revenue, the N.H.L. might have been in position to declare an impasse, impose new work rules and end the lockout, inviting players to return to work. 
 The players would very likely have declared a strike at that point, and the league could have stocked its teams with replacement players.
 Before the injunction was granted at the end of March in the baseball dispute, clubs had recruited replacement players and had them in spring training. It was never determined if they would have begun the season with them. It was, however, not likely.
 If the N.H.L. were to declare an impasse, it would involve other elements, namely Canadian labor law. There is disagreement among Canadian labor lawyers whether Canadian teams could use replacement players. 
 But the league won't say if it had impasse plans before or would have them in the future. The union would not comment on potential league strategy.
 There is another difference that could have an impact on future developments. In 1994-95, the N.L.R.B. was a Democratic board under the Clinton White House. The board is now Republican and might not take a favorable view of issues supported by the union. Republican boards are historically kinder to employers than to employees.
 No one knows what the outcome would have been had the board had a Republican majority in 1995. 
 Although baseball players returned to work in April 1995, the two sides did not reach a new labor agreement until October 1996. But at least they played the 1995 World Series.
 What about that poll idea, World Series or hockey season?
 ''That's a debate I won't get into,'' Selig said. ''But the World Series not being played was certainly in the national consciousness and very painful for a lot of people.''

Room for Improvement
 Despite the perfect ending to their year -- eight victories in their last eight games -- the Boston Red Sox were not perfect last season. So says their manager, Terry Francona.
 ''Two things jump out at me,'' Francona said.
 ''Our pitching staff needs to hold base runners better. We lost some one-run games, probably more than our share. When you're in a one-run situation and you don't hold base runners, it's difficult to win one-run games.''
 No. 2, Francona said: ''I think we can pick up our base running. Not that we're going to become a base-stealing team, but we need to be an intelligent team that takes bases when they're supposed to.''

Pedro the Irreplaceable
 If there was any question about the value the Red Sox put on Pedro Martinez, the erstwhile ace of their pitching staff, Jason Varitek, his catcher the past seven seasons, offered this blunt assessment in discussing the team's three new starters, David Wells, Matt Clement and Wade Miller:
 ''You're talking about an irreplaceable pitcher in baseball. We can't replace Pedro Martinez. I won't even go down that road trying to. These guys are different guys. None of them should pitch with the thought process of replacing Pedro Martinez. It can't be done. He's been the best pitcher in a decade.''

A Thumb Down for 'Juiced'
 Jose Canseco didn't write his book, ''Juiced,'' to gain literary accolades, but he should be happy that Curt Schilling isn't reviewing it for some publication.
 ''I couldn't finish the book,'' Schilling, a Red Sox pitcher, said. ''It got to the point where I thought it was unreadable. You can't stick your head in the sand and say it's all lies. But who's to say what is true and what isn't? I can only go with what I know. It's unfortunate to see someone go in that direction. He's obviously being bitter that his career went the way it did. But I don't think he has anybody to blame but himself.''

HEADLINE: The Mommy Trap

BYLINE: By Judith Shulevitz. 
Judith Shulevitz is working on a book about the Sabbath.

 BODY:

PERFECT MADNESS
Motherhood in the Age of Anxiety.
By Judith Warner.
327 pp. Riverhead
Books. $23.95.
 Manifestoes blast their way into the popular consciousness on two kinds of fuel: recognition (we see ourselves in them) and rage (we can no longer tolerate the injustice they describe). Judith Warner's ''Perfect Madness: Motherhood in the Age of Anxiety'' brims with both. She clearly means for her denunciation of American-style mothering to do for overstressed 21st-century upper-middle-class American women what Betty Friedan's ''Feminine Mystique'' did for underemployed 20th-century ones. ''Perfect Madness'' is not half as good as ''The Feminine Mystique'' -- not as painfully accurate or cleverly argued -- but, like Friedan, Warner channels a big, explosive feeling, which she identifies as frustration at ''the mommy mystique'' or, more resonantly, ''this mess.'' Since I and other mothers I know expend a great deal of energy trying to quash the suspicion that our once carefully groomed resumes now look as shabby and unpromising as our toy-strewn homes and lumpy midsections, I read most of Warner's long and somewhat repetitive book in a single sitting, and so, I think, will fellow travelers on the mommy track. The mess, c'est moi; the injustice is that it doesn't matter how committed I am to my work or how efficient I become. As soon as I began bearing children I hit, not a glass ceiling, but a brick wall. It is no longer cool to say stuff like this, not even in female company. After God knows how many thousands of books, articles and talk shows on the rapid-aging process human resources professionals politely call ''the work-life balance,'' we have had about as much as we can stomach on the subject. We are not zesty, pie-eyed, would-be superwomen. We acknowledge life's limitations and the needs of our children and adjust our ambitions accordingly. On the other hand, just because we have issue fatigue, that doesn't mean we don't have an issue. Judith Warner, a biographer of Hillary Clinton and Newt Gingrich and the co-author of a book with Howard Dean, interviewed 150 mostly well-off women, about half of them in and around Washington, and wrote up her observations in a breathy women's-mag style that would seem to disqualify her somewhat for the job of filtering out the chatter and identifying the threat to our emotional and economic security. (She confined her interviews largely to upper-middle-class women because, she says, images of upper-middle-class motherhood tend to crowd out all other kinds in magazines and on television and therefore exert an outsize pressure on discussions of the subject -- a claim with merit, but still a remarkably circular way of going about things.) Then again, as the defense secretary recently said, you go to war with the army you have. 
 And so, to war. Warner has two points to make. The first is that, in affluent America, mothering has gone from an art to a cult, with devotees driving themselves to ever more baroque extremes to appease the goddess of perfect motherhood. Warner, who has two children, made this discovery upon her return from a stay in Paris, where, she says, mothers who benefit from state-subsidized support systems -- child care, preschools, medical services -- never dream of surrendering jobs or social lives to stay home 24/7 with their kids. In the absence of such calming assistance, however, American moms are turning themselves into physically and financially depleted drones. 
 The truth of this last observation is perceptible on even a short visit to any faintly tony suburb, though it's doubtful that only mothers have lost their sense of proportion. Parents no longer set up metal swing sets in corners of their backyards; they hire professionals to erect sprawling wooden castles that consume half the lawn. Parents line up at 5 a.m. to get slots in just the right neighborhood preschool and bring their children to specialists upon noticing the slightest delay in speech or motor coordination. Desperate to maximize their children's levels of attachment and developmental capacity, they turn marital beds into family beds, flash ''Baby Einstein'' cards at their 3-month-olds, enroll toddlers in nonstop improving activities, and give up quiet evenings at home to plan Girl Scout cookie drives -- ''Girl Scout cookie meetings? At 8 o'clock at night?'' exclaims Warner. (That last surely is a mother-only activity.) The ex-professional stay-at-home mothers who, like haughty high priests, identify each new form of self-sacrifice set the pace for the still working ones, some of whom leave their jobs to keep up. 
 Warner tends toward hyperbole, but she strikes me as right about the basic phenomenon. In a society that measures status in consumer goods and hard-to-come-by symbols of achievement -- grades, awards, brand-name colleges -- the scramble for advantage is bound to propel American upper-middle-class parents into exponentially goofier displays of one-upsmanship. Try giving your 3-year-old an old-fashioned cake-and-balloon birthday party at home, with neither facilitator nor gift bags, and you'll see that Warner's onto something, and that it's harder to opt out than you'd think. Allison Pearson was a lot funnier about the anthropology of parental rivalry in her novel, ''I Don't Know How She Does It,'' and incidentally revealed that elites use their children to jockey for status in other developed nations, not just in the United States. (Pearson's hyperjudgmental mothers lived in London.) But then, fiction is always better on the details than sociology.
 There's more than just detail, however, to back up the theory that parents put in more time than they used to. According to the Families and Work Institute's most recent five-year study of the national work force, children receive on average one hour more of parental attention on work days than they did 25 years ago. Translated out of the levelling language of statistical averages, that means many, many hours of helping with homework, cheering at basketball games and schlepping to music classes. (Interestingly, the study says that it's men who are putting in the extra hour, while working women spend the same amount of time as before: 3.4 hours per workday. Men now average 2.7 hours.) Insofar as Warner implies that these new standards of parenting are driving women from the work force, she may be exaggerating. She is right to observe, however, that something is taking them out of action. A 2002 Census Bureau report shows that from 1998 to 2000 the percentage of women in the work force with small children declined from 59 to 55 percent, reversing a general upward trend; 13 percent more children were being raised at home by full-time mothers in 2002 than in 1994. 
 These changes may seem relatively small, but small changes can have cascading effects. Mothers experience them at the most personal level. Take the woman who decides to scale back when her baby is born. Her smaller paycheck makes her husband feel that he must bring in a bigger one, or at least make sure not to slip into a lower income bracket. That means longer hours and less time at home. Before long, the wife cuts back her hours even more to cope with the increased housework, shopping and cooking she has to do, and to care for the baby, who, as he gets older, needs more love and educational enrichment, not less. Soon she is wondering whether to keep her expensive part-time baby sitter (who is probably looking around for a full-time position) and whether her career, now barely recognizable as such, is worth what it costs to maintain it. ''Was I really a good enough writer to justify the sacrifice?'' Warner wondered when she found herself in that situation. ''Or should I, at long last, just hang it up?'' 
 I hate to think what America would be like should even the small number of women who could afford it decide just to hang it up. One imagines the halls of law firms, businesses, universities and newsrooms slowly thinning out of all but the youngest women, who, over time, would tend to be confined to jobs that don't lead anywhere, since no boss would want to see his investment in a fast-track employee rewarded by her leaving to have a baby. At the moment, more women than men get master's degrees and as many women as men get professional degrees, but that, too, could change, if a diminished idea of what women are capable of starts deflecting them from even beginning serious careers. (That a dearth of women in a particular field leads directly to doubt about their suitability for that field was made amply clear by the controversy last month over whether women lack the genetic capacity to succeed as professors of math and science. Maybe they do and maybe they don't, but you don't need genetics to explain why women might fail to rise to the top of a profession that requires an 80-hour workweek.) 
 This leads to Warner's second point, which is more openly political than her first. Our neurotic quest to perfect the mechanics of mothering, she says, can be interpreted as an effort to do on an individual level what we've stopped trying to do on a society-wide one. In her view, it is the lack of family-friendly policies common in Europe that backs American mothers into the corner described above -- policies that would promote ''flexible, affordable, locally available, high-quality'' day care; mandate quality controls for that day care; require or enable businesses to give paid parental leave; make health insurance available for part-time workers; and so on. 
 Unfortunately, Warner doesn't say how we might organize to get such policies passed in a rightward-drifting, Europe-hating America. She is content merely to criticize social conservatives, on the one hand, and old-school feminists, on the other, for making such legislation unthinkable. (Some feminists fear that a focus on motherhood and the needs of children will distract from the goal of workplace equality, though I think Warner overstates their influence.) Nor does she grapple with research that suggests a downside to European-style family legislation. One typical study, for example, argues that cushy state supports for Swedish mothers have weakened the bonds of marriage in that society and undermined the family. Such arguments (in my opinion) often lack context -- any signs of dissolving family ties, such as rising levels of divorce, that you can point to in Europe tend to be worse in the United States -- but Warner ought to have dealt with them. 
 In the end, she acknowledges that life isn't perfect for French mothers, either. ''There is a price they pay for the wonderful (and expensive) benefits they enjoy: a pervasive and all-but-unchallenged kind of institutional sexism,'' she writes. ''It can keep women of childbearing age from being hired. And can condemn others to being fired when they fully avail themselves of the 'rights' so readily accorded to them.'' Warner signs off after conceding this point, as if to say, c'est la vie, but I think it goes to the heart of the problem. We can and should write more maternal supports into law, but until we change our bedrock assumptions about what the proper balance of work and life should be, women will always pay a price for interrupting their careers to have children. Non-upper-middle-class women who have no choice but to keep working will continue putting in the kinds of days that make them strangers to their children, while those with more options will either tear their hearts out at not exercising them or drop out of the work force and apply their skill at climbing career ladders to pushing their children up them. 
 There is reason to believe -- to hope -- their children will resist. The Families and Work Institute study cited above found that, compared with members of the baby boom generation, younger college-educated workers seem markedly less willing to sacrifice everything to advance in their careers. Many of the younger workers yearn to work fewer hours, and say they would turn down promotions if the new jobs required longer days and more work brought home -- claims that may well prove untrue in practice, but nonetheless say a lot about the people making them. More young professionals rank their families as equal in importance to their jobs, or even greater. More young women than men hold these views, not surprisingly, but what is surprising is how many more young men interviewed in 2002 disagreed with the statement that it is ''much better for everyone involved if the man earns the money and the woman takes care of the home and children,'' compared with young men interviewed 25 years earlier. You could dismiss this as just the young folk regurgitating the gender ideology they learned in school, except that more young fathers also ''walk the talk,'' in the jargon of corporate America: they spend an average of one more hour a day with their children than baby boomers do.
 Which brings us back to overparenting. Warner deplores its dangers both to us and to our children, who, she says, are likely to wind up as spoiled, callow, allergy-prone, risk-averse success machines with no inner lives. I rather doubt it. Social scientists and commentators have been warning of the ill effects of overparenting since parental advice books first began appearing in bookstores, but each new generation seems about as agreeable or disagreeable as the last. For all its excesses, overparenting is still preferable to its alternative, which was depicted with quiet sadness by the sociologist Arlie Russell Hochschild in her 1997 book, ''The Time Bind.'' Hochschild studied a Fortune 500 company with exemplary work-life balance policies for both men and women and discovered that few mothers and almost no fathers took advantage of them. Some were afraid of losing their jobs; some couldn't cope with the fear that they'd be diminished in their bosses' eyes; some wanted overtime pay; but a majority eventually admitted that they liked life in the office and even on the plant floor better than life at home. Work was orderly and companionable. Home crackled with the anger and acting-out of children cycled through jury-rigged baby-sitting arrangements and yanked through their lives like tiny factory workers keeping pace with a speedup. 
 Hochschild interviewed only workers employed by the company, not those who had dropped out to stay home, so hers was a world perhaps overly drained of nurture. But the majority of women now work, and given the growing gap between the wealthy few and the less-wealthy many, that probably won't change. With the rise of the service economy and companies that spread their production process across several continents, Americans are more likely to be working longer and during evenings and weekends, making child care even more complicated. What Hochschild forces us to consider is that we're losing the ability to imagine a world in which we work less and at more reasonable hours, and therefore that we no longer bother to fight to bring that world into being. It is our own internalized workaholism that threatens to devour us and our children -- that, and the increasingly untenable absence of a public infrastructure of care. 
 Overparenting has a lot in common with overwork. Both make economists happy, because they lead us to buy more stuff, whether that stuff is baby-wipe warmers or gourmet meals delivered after hours to our offices. Both are powered by fear of a loss of face. But the two also come into conflict, and therein may lie one route to salvation. It is mothers caught between overparenting and overwork who have the strongest incentive to push back against the forces that drive them. I wouldn't go so far as to echo what one writer recently said in The New York Times Magazine, which is that mothers opting out of their careers herald a new revolution, because revolutions tend to end badly, and this one seems pretty inauspicious. But insofar as mothers with jobs and mothers without them could conceivably band together to form a very large interest group, we do represent a whopping opportunity for change. Whether we take that opportunity depends on whether we can pull ourselves out of our mess long enough to persuade those around us to clean up theirs. 

I Listened to my friends, listened to talk radio, to the mothers on the playground, and to my daughter's nursery school teachers, and I found it all -- the general culture of motherhood in America -- oppressive. The pressure to perform, to attain levels of perfect selflessness was insane. And it was, I thought, as I listened to one more anguished friend wringing her hands over the work-family ''balance,'' and another expressing her guilt at not having ''succeeded'' at breast-feeding, driving American mothers crazy.
 Myself along with them. 
 It took very little time on the ground in America before I found myself becoming unrecognizable. I bought an S.U.V. I signed my unathletic elder daughter up for soccer. Other 3-year-olds in her class were taking gymnastics, too, and art, and swimming and music. I signed her up for ballet. I bought a small library of pre-K skill books. I went around in a state of quiet panic. From ''Perfect Madness.''

HEADLINE: The Cuban Import

BYLINE: By Robert Andrew Powell. 
Robert Andrew Powell is the author of ''We Own This Game: A Season in the Adult World of Youth Football.'' This is his first article for the magazine.

 BODY:
A question mark hovers above Kendry Morales like a halo. One of the newest members of the Los Angeles Angels of Anaheim baseball team, which begins spring training this week, he may be the best young hitter ever to defect from Cuba. Or, just as likely, he may be another overhyped bust, like so many Cuban prospects before him. When I met him last summer, a couple of months after his flight from Cuba, at his temporary home in the Dominican Republic, there were only two people who seemed certain of his success. One was Morales himself. The other was John Di Manno, an accountant from Toronto.
 Wherever Morales went, Di Manno was by his side. They slept in the same apartment in Santo Domingo, the capital of the Dominican Republic. Di Manno hired the cabs for the 40-minute drive to the complex where Morales worked out every morning and sat in the cramped back seat. Along the way, the car climbed drive-shaft-scraping speed bumps and passed by roadside vendors selling mangoes, cigarettes and coconut water tapped with the swift slice of a machete. Morales, folded into the front passenger seat, sang along to the radio. When the car drove by an attractive woman, Morales reached over to honk the horn. Di Manno chuckled approvingly. 
 The way Di Manno followed Morales around, he could have been mistaken for a personal valet. At La Loma del Suenos, a collection of fields rented and operated by the New York Yankees, Di Manno carried the player's bat, spikes, hat and batting gloves. When Morales broke a sweat, Di Manno pulled a fresh shirt from an equipment bag. When Morales requested a cup of water, Di Manno trotted off to find a cooler and some waxy paper cups.
 Di Manno told me that he was an accountant only by training, that he had evolved into more of an entrepreneur. His partners back in Canada, at DSP Chartered Accountants, accepted his new job description at face value. ''I'm doing all the actual accounting for him,'' Adam Sorrenti, one of the firm's partners, said. ''He hasn't been seen around here in four months. When he gets back, if he ever comes back, he's got to decide what he wants to do -- be an accountant or be a baseball agent.''
 Di Manno apparently wants to be a baseball agent. For several years he had been trying to hook up with a top Cuban player willing to defect to the United States. There were some false starts -- like the time, according to another agent, Di Manno pursued a promising pitcher only to lose him to that agent. But finally, in Morales, Di Manno had found his man.
 ''In this business, it's all about landing the right guy,'' Di Manno said. ''That one big client that can lead to more opportunities down the road, many more opportunities.''
 He spent months winning Morales's confidence, meeting with him in Cuba, phoning him from Canada, dangling before him all the dollar signs available in the major leagues. When Morales finally defected, last June, Di Manno was waiting for him in Miami. Morales signed a personal-services contract binding the two men even though Di Manno was not yet an agent certified by Major League Baseball and had never represented another athlete.
 I flew to the Dominican Republic with as many questions about Di Manno as scouts had about Morales. Scouts wondered if Morales could field, or hit major-league pitching. I wondered if Di Manno was a shark, a hustler holding undue influence over a 21-year-old new to a free market system. After a few days in the company of both men, however, I wondered who exactly was the savvy businessman and who had just stepped off the boat.
 ''It's amazing how quickly he picked up on capitalism, on stuff like leasing,'' Di Manno said. ''In Cuba you can't rent or own, yet he'll ask me late at night, 'What do you think about buying this apartment building, putting money down and paying off the mortgage with the rent?' It's incredible.''
There is a calmness about Morales. It's a trait he shares with many elite athletes, a certainty that if he works hard at his game, the details and problems of life will take care of themselves. That's the way it has been so far. Baseball gave him a better life in Cuba, an air-conditioned three-bedroom house and more food on the table for his mother and his young wife (who remains in Cuba).
 Like many boys in Cuba, he started playing the game when he was very young. By 18, Morales had emerged as a star on Havana's Industriales, a team in Cuba's domestic league. He played first base, third base, right field and even pitcher for the Cuban junior national team. He hit a grand slam to help the senior national team defeat Taiwan during the 2003 Baseball World Cup, which was held in Havana.
 He was leading the Cuban league in hits in late 2003 when he was suspended after authorities suspected he was trying to defect. By last summer, two months after he did defect, and after nearly a year spent outside baseball, Morales looked overweight more than athletic. He stood a bit taller than six feet and was thick in the trunk, and his face was rounded with the last remnants of baby fat. A stomach as broad as his shoulders made him resemble a water tank. His ropy forearms -- his most distinctive muscle set -- were thicker than some men's legs.
 His swing revealed his grace. It's a good swing, compact and violent. Power from both sides of the plate -- that's what his advocates always say. That's his gift, his talent. Batting left or batting right, he sprays line drives so hard and fast that they often lead to stand-up doubles and runs batted in.
 ''He has hitting potential,'' Carlos Rios, the Yankees' head scout for Latin America, told me back in August, when the Yankees were considering a bid for Morales. ''Any blind man can figure that out.''
 When he was not hitting, Morales moved in slow motion, conserving his energy much the way Henry Aaron did. Peter Gammons, the ESPN baseball analyst, has said that Morales has carried himself with the air of a veteran ever since he was a teenager in Cuba's development program.
 Morales expressed mixed feelings about the quality of his life in Cuba. When prompted, he responded with the standard exile party line, guaranteed to play in Miami. ''Castro didn't allow freedom,'' he said. ''When we got on that boat and left Cuba, my first thought was that I was a free man, that I wasn't a prisoner anymore.''
 He complained that he was paid only $5 a month to play baseball. Yet he also admitted that $5 stretched pretty far: the large air-conditioned house; Industriales fans helping out with food.
 ''Everyone in Cuba struggles, and I struggled as well, but after I started to play better, things improved,'' he said.
More than 100 Cuban baseball players have defected since 1991, when the pitcher Rene Arocha broke away from the national team during a layover in the Miami airport. Very few of the players who followed his lead have enjoyed successful major-league careers. Most have flamed out with blown elbows or inferior play. Only three Cuban pitchers have thrown more than 200 innings in a single major-league season.
 In less than a season with the Yankees last year, Jose Contreras was demoted twice to the minor leagues and then traded to the Chicago White Sox. Danys Baez was cut from the Cleveland Indians after losing his spot as a closer. (He has since landed with the Tampa Bay Devil Rays.) Soon after Morales defected to Florida, three other Cuban players defected to Mexico. None of them have signed a contract.
 A few defectors have succeeded. Rey Ordonez won three Gold Gloves at shortstop for the Mets. The center fielder Alex Sanchez bats leadoff in Detroit. Livan Hernandez, a pitcher, was the M.V.P. of the 1997 World Series. Orlando (El Duque) Hernandez, Livan's half-brother, won his own World Series rings with the Yankees as a pitcher.
 Despite this uneven record, there is true talent in Cuba, and because major-league teams are barred by law from scouting the island, Cuban baseball players have long enjoyed the lure of the forbidden.
 ''It's exactly like Cuban cigars,'' says the Cuban baseball historian Milton Jamail. ''The players are almost always overvalued. The players may be really good, but they're still overvalued because they're exotic.''
 Even in Communist Cuba, Morales came to grasp his market value. Players he considered himself to be every bit as good as -- if not better than -- had signed eye-popping major-league contracts. The Yankees agreed to pay Jose Contreras $8 million a year. Livan Hernandez earns $7 million a year. The pull to follow his peers to the U.S. was there for Morales, though it was not strong initially.
 ''I knew that one could have a better life in North America, but I never really thought of it as an option, because at that time I'd never really had any problems with the government,'' Morales told me.
 Sometime after he first met Di Manno, about two years ago, Morales changed his mind. While he never publicly said he planned to leave the country, government officials grew wary of Morales's commitment to the revolution. In November 2003, during an Olympic qualifying tournament in Panama, a Cuban official pulled Morales off the field in the third inning of a game and drove him straight to the Cuban Embassy. Morales was flown back to the island, sequestered on the airplane in the middle of an empty row of seats. He never played for the national team again and was permanently suspended from his club team in December.
 ''I started to think then I might as well defect,'' he said.
 Morales claimed he tried and failed to leave Cuba eight times before he finally succeeded, on June 8. In a coastal town he declined to identify, Morales joined a former pitching coach and 17 others for a clandestine trip to Key West.
 The traverse of the Florida Straits has been mythologized with tales of dehydration and starvation. After El Duque's defection in 1997, stories arose of his having fended off a shark. On a tipsy raft, the trip can last as long as three days. ''It took about four hours,'' Morales said of his trip, a sure clue that he was smuggled on a go-fast boat.
Cubans who set foot on Florida soil are almost always allowed to stay. When Morales was released from the immigration detention center in Miami, John Di Manno was there to pick him up.
 ''I used to know John from Cuba,'' Morales said. ''We used to communicate on the phone in Cuba. After I got out, I called John, and John came over.''
 The decision to call Di Manno is one the aspiring agent told me was simply good fortune on his part. The Miami Herald reported that there was a six-figure bidding war for Morales involving at least four agents, a charge Di Manno flatly denies. Yet one of those competing agents, Juan Iglesias, based in Miami, insisted Morales did try to auction himself to the highest bidder.
 ''I was contacted directly,'' said Iglesias, who represents Livan Hernandez. ''You can quote me: Kendry was trying to make a deal.'' 
 Another agent based in Miami, Henry Vilar, told me that he, too, was offered the right to represent Morales in exchange for an upfront cash payment.
 The competition for Morales didn't stop after he signed with Di Manno. Before arranging to move Morales to the Dominican Republic, where the player would not be subject to baseball's annual draft and so would enjoy greater negotiating leverage than he would in the United States, Di Manno hid out with Morales for a month in Orlando. Together they rode roller coasters at DisneyWorld and fattened up on chicken wings at a Hooters restaurant.
 ''I had to get out of Miami,'' Di Manno said. ''There was this group of people from, I guess I'll say a third-world country, who had befriended him in Cuba. As soon as Kendry got to Miami, they started calling for him four, five, six times a day, every day. They were calling his mom telling her that he'd been kidnapped and was being held hostage. Kendry had to call her and say, 'No, I'm staying in a nice house and I'm eating well and I'm being taken care of.'''
 Di Manno is 40 years old. In a polo shirt and khaki shorts, with his receding hairline trimmed to a buzz cut, he looks like the adult embodiment of Charlie Brown. A steady diet of cigarettes has stained his teeth. He smokes when he's bored or nervous, the cigarettes dancing around his fingers while his eyes dart left and right. It's as if he's always on the lookout for spies or rival agents, which he is.
 Cockroaches, he called them, men who sidled up to Morales on the street or even in the field at practice, denigrating Di Manno, saying he didn't know what he was doing, how he had never represented a player before, how Morales would be so much better off switching to a real professional.
 Di Manno insists he is a professional. He talks like a professional, anyway. ''In this business, you have to have a team,'' he said. ''You can't do it alone. I've surrounded myself with people I can trust -- because in this business it's dog eat dog -- and I let them do it.''
 An immigration attorney in the Dominican Republic helped Morales obtain residency there. A crew of marketers had been mobilized in Toronto, Di Manno said, ready to affix the Kendry Morales brand to beer, bats, shoes and other endorsable products. Discussions with major-league teams were subcontracted to David Valdes, a 32-year-old agent based in Miami, a man whose e-mail goes through the mortgage company where he works, and which he can fall back on if the agent business doesn't pan out.
 ''He's the money man,'' Valdes said of Di Manno. ''I'm the certified agent of record, but he's the money man. He's like the C.E.O. of this operation.'' If Morales makes the majors, then Di Manno, as his representative, is eligible to become a league-certified agent who would no longer need a middleman like Valdes. (Breaking in as the agent of a major-league player is a bit of a Catch-22. Only union-certified agents like Valdes are officially allowed to negotiate with major-league teams like the Angels. Once a player signs with a team, and is added to its 40-man roster, that player can turn around and appoint whomever he pleases to be his representative. Only then is that new agent allowed to apply for union certification.)
 Di Manno's move into the sports business grew out of his love for Cuba in general. He had been vacationing there for years and has a Cuban-born wife; they take their young son back to visit her family every year. On the island, Communism doesn't foster the celebrity posse; there isn't much of a barrier between athletes and average citizens. Di Manno had little trouble penetrating Morales's circle.
 ''The first time I met him we talked and clicked,'' Di Manno recalled. ''There was a little patio in Havana where he was talking to a few friends. One of the people I was with recognized him and introduced me to him. We kept in contact, talking occasionally. 'How you doing?' This and that. I saw a business opportunity.''
 Before he hooked up with Morales, Di Manno established a relationship with Maels Rodriguez, probably the least fortunate of the recent defectors. When Rodriguez fled Cuba in 2003, he was touted as a sure-fire major-league player -- not just a starter but an ace, an All-Star. His fastball had been measured at more than 100 miles per hour. His agent, Henry Vilar, established residency for Rodriguez in El Salvador, then announced that the $32 million contract Jose Contreras signed with the Yankees was a good starting point for negotiations. Some 15 teams sent scouts to watch Rodriguez pitch in San Salvador. But at those workouts, the baseball never traveled into the 90's, much less triple digits. Rodriguez has yet to sign a contract with any team.
 ''I didn't know who Di Manno was until he called me after Maels signed with me,'' Vilar told me. ''I got a call from Di Manno saying he had a lot of money invested in trips to Cuba visiting Maels and that he's been good to him and that he can't believe he got [expletive] over by him.'' Di Manno claimed he did not try to represent Rodriguez.
 Although Vilar landed Rodriguez initially, he eventually lost the pitcher. After relocating Rodriguez to the Dominican Republic in an attempt to restart his career, Vilar flew to Miami to celebrate his son's fifth birthday. When he returned to Santo Domingo two days later, Rodriguez disappeared. The pitcher eventually resurfaced under contract with another agent in Miami.
 In a lawsuit filed in November in Miami-Dade Circuit Court, Vilar claimed that he invested more than $500,000 of his own money in Rodriguez and a second Cuban player, a figure he told me is at least $200,000 below what he actually spent.
 ''It's not just the two players,'' Vilar said. ''It's also family members, wives and best friends who were living life large here. I have a lot of my money in real estate, and I had sold off some of my properties to have the money available to do this business deal.'' After I met with Vilar, in the family's cigar shop in South Miami, located in a strip mall between the Big Tomato pizzeria and a beauty shop, the parties to the lawsuit agreed to submit to arbitration.
 Di Manno said the dollar figures in Vilar's lawsuit sounded plausible. ''I don't really know the particular details,'' he told me, ''but there are a lot of costs. Room and board for four or five months, travel -- it starts accumulating. When you get involved with international players, there are a lot of up-front costs.''
 Like Vilar, Di Manno became personally leveraged in his Cuban investment. Also like Vilar, Di Manno enjoys no guarantees that the time and money he advanced Morales will be recouped. It's almost impossibly tricky for any athlete to make a major-league roster. More than a few pro scouts doubt Morales's ability to become one of the lucky few, even though he has signed with the Angels.
The lessons of Maels Rodriguez were perhaps the primary reason that Di Manno harnessed himself so completely to Kendry Morales. He relocated his entire life to Santo Domingo. He stopped looking at clients' tax returns, though he said he could have been billing $350 an hour for his accounting expertise. Even factoring in an unfavorable Canadian exchange rate, his time was valuable.
 The negotiations with major-league teams dragged on for months, into late November. Di Manno and Morales tried to stick to a routine. They would catch their taxi at 7 a.m. for the drive from Santo Domingo to the Yankees' baseball complex. Kendry practiced his swing in batting-cage sessions and lifted weights in a modest gym. Some mornings he worked on fielding drills -- Morales is not known for his defense. As Morales scooped up ground balls sprayed by a Yankees coach, Di Manno stood on first base with a mitt, collecting the balls in a duffel bag.
 The Yankee imprint was everywhere at La Loma del Suenos, which in English is known as the Mountain of Dreams. The six infields were meticulously manicured. The bushes were groomed to resemble the arched wainscoting of Yankee Stadium. In deference to the Yankees, who insist players in their organization be clean-cut, Morales had taped a Band-Aid over a small gold stud in his ear.
 The Yankees have a history of foreign investment, which includes El Duque and Contreras. Yet the team lost interest in Morales, perhaps because Contreras was such an expensive disappointment. So Morales proceeded to showcase his swing at compounds run by other major-league teams. The Mariners were interested for a while, then passed. A Florida Marlins scout declared Morales a legitimate hitter, if not quite ready for the majors. A scout for the Tigers flew back to Detroit unwilling to offer Morales a contract.
 ''I think the guy has the chance to be an average offensive player in the major leagues,'' said a scouting director for one of the few teams that expressed sustained interest in Morales. (He asked not to be identified because he didn't want to poison any future dealings with the Angels, Morales or Di Manno.) ''And that remains to be seen. He's an average player to be sure.'' 
 Every afternoon Morales ate and napped in the apartment he shared with Di Manno and Di Manno's wife and son. Morales was inclined to stay in all evening watching baseball on television, but at least a few nights every week Di Manno dragged him out. They ate pork sandwiches while sitting on a rocky seawall that juts off the Malecon. Sometimes they played pool in a bar until the electricity failed, as it did for hours almost every night. As the calendar advanced toward December, Di Manno worried that Morales would start playing Dominican winter ball without the safety net of a contract, leaving him vulnerable to a slump or an injury that would reduce his market value.
 ''Our initial assessment of them was that they were in kind of over their heads,'' the scouting director said, referring to Di Manno and his partner, David Valdes. ''The numbers they were talking were unrealistic in our opinion. I think they really didn't have a good perspective for the kind of market it was.''
 Only the Angels were willing to take a chance. The team flew two scouts down to spend a week in Santo Domingo. They stayed in the same hotel as Morales and Di Manno. The scouts shared meals, playing Ping-Pong with Morales after dinner. After they returned to the U.S., the Angels offered Morales a contract, which he and Di Manno accepted. 
 The contract is two-tiered, depending on whether Morales makes the Angels or is relegated to the minors. If Morales makes the Angels this spring and stays with the team for the next six years, he will earn at least $6 million, on top of the $3 million signing bonus he gets now. If he stays in the minors all six years, his minimum earnings sink to $1.5 million total after his signing bonus. The contract is unusual: in the fantastic economy of Major League Baseball, $9 million over six years for an established player is outrageously low, an almost-criminal steal for the Angels. Yet if Morales fails to make the team, his salary -- even with its hefty cut -- will make him one of the best-compensated minor leaguers ever.
 ''All I'll say is we're happy with it,'' Di Manno said. ''It's a very good contract. It's a six-year major-league contract with a sizable signing bonus and a lot of guaranteed money.''
 Kendry Morales, born into Communism, unproved and unwanted by almost every major-league team, is now a millionaire. It's not clear what Di Manno's take will be. If Kendry establishes himself with the Angels, Di Manno stands to make about $80,000 a year, minus taxes and whatever cut he must slip his partner Valdes. 
 For Di Manno to really cash in, though, Morales must play six years of exceptional professional baseball -- and then, as he prepares to sign a new major-league contract, he must retain Di Manno as his agent. A number of reasons make that a difficult proposition to count on, however. One of the biggest hang-ups: most Latin players change agents four times in their professional careers, according to Vilar.
 ''The player has to back you up,'' Vilar said. ''That's the biggest thing. Di Manno can be there'' doing everything -- ''but the next day Kendry can still be gone.''
 Di Manno trusts Morales to show loyalty. They are a team now, he said, more like brothers than mere business partners. 
 ''Kendry is a very intelligent man,'' Di Manno said. ''He knows I've made an investment in terms of dollars. And let's be honest, he is a very good investment on my part. I stand to make a very good return for my work.''
 The investment will pay off, Di Manno said. He is sure of it.

 Morales at the Angels' training complex in the Dominican Republic. The big money, if there is to be any, will come from his swing, which is compact and able to shoot line drives from both sides of the plate. (Photographs by Stefan Ruiz for The New York Times)
