Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section 3; Column 1; SundayBusiness; SUNDAY MONEY: INVESTING; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 1167 words

HEADLINE: Four Strong Emerging Markets. But How to Play Them?

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT

 BODY:
WHAT do Brazil, Russia, India and China have in common? They have the greatest prospects for long-term economic growth among big emerging-market countries, in the view of many analysts, who are bullish about investing in them.
 Goldman Sachs calls the four countries the BRIC's, for their first initials, and many analysts say that all four have growing middle classes and improving domestic infrastructures, and are likely to play dominant roles in the global economy. 
 ''The strong growth in these economies should mean good growth in stock returns and currency appreciation over the long term,'' said Dominic Wilson, senior global economist at Goldman Sachs.
 For Americans, making a focused investment in all four of these countries isn't easy, or necessarily desirable. For one thing, no American mutual fund concentrates on just these four countries, although some firms are considering the possibility. Christian Deseglise, product manager for emerging markets at HSBC Asset Management, said his firm had just created an overseas BRIC fund for wealthy European investors and may start an American counterpart soon. 
 More crucial, though, is that some strategists say it wouldn't be wise to put too much money into these markets. Even if the four countries fulfill their economic potential, their domestic stock markets will not necessarily boom.
 Over the short term, emerging-market performance doesn't neatly track economic growth. Last year, for example, the gross domestic product of Brazil grew by only 5 percent, but its stock market jumped about 30 percent in United States dollar terms. And in China, the stock market was virtually flat despite economic growth of 9 percent. 
 The Brazilian market benefited because it had been so depressed by earlier concerns over the 2002 election of President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, who some investors feared was unfriendly toward business. Concerns about corporate governance in China continue to worry international investors who are still skittish about putting money there. 
 ''There are so many difficult issues for foreign investors in China,'' said Brad Durham, an analyst at Emerging Portfolio Fund Research in Boston. He said that foreigners could buy only certain designated shares on Chinese exchanges and that a lack of regulation had led to trading abuses. 
 For those reasons, he said, making big focused bets is not wise for most investors. ''Retail investors should not go into single-country stocks,'' he said. ''They tend to be volatile, and you have to monitor the market regularly.'' 
 Instead, many experts said, the best plan may be to stick to a diversified fund that includes broad exposure to the four major emerging markets, though is not limited to them. Jacob Rees-Mogg, who manages the Eaton Vance Emerging Markets fund, says he does not believe that opportunities for investment are any better in the BRIC's than in emerging-market countries in general. ''There is no reason to exclude the other countries,'' he said. His fund's largest country allocation -- 20 percent -- is currently South Korea. That is partly because domestic consumption is picking up there, he said, after a huge increase in credit card debt. 
 Another expert on emerging markets, D.Kirk Henry, who manages the Dreyfus Premier Emerging Markets fund, said that ''many of the big markets in Asia have been dependent on selling to Western markets.'' Mr. Henry added, ''Now we are seeing a shift toward Asia, where domestic consumption is more important.'' The fund gained 22.9 percent a year, on average, over the last three years.
 For the future, the BRIC's have great allure. Their representation in global equity markets, measured by total capitalization could soar to as much as 10 percent by 2020 from 3.5 percent today, Goldman Sachs estimated. But some investors say that it is too risky to move much money into a single market like China. Mr. Rees-Mogg, for one, said that his fund had little investment there because of corporate governance problems. ''In many companies, investors are minority shareholders alongside the government or a family,'' he said. ''A family-controlled company may decide to diversify into a completely different line of business, for instance. And though the government is a better partner, you have to be concerned because only a small percentage of the stocks in many companies actually trades. For example, PetroChina is a $100 billion company of which the government owns 90 percent. It can decide to issue new stock at any time.'' 
 Whether the investment is in individual stocks or country-specific mutual funds, political developments in emerging markets can have a big impact. Consider that the Indian stock market fell 17 percent over two days in May after parliamentary elections permitted the Indian National Congress party to retake power.
 Of course, markets can stage quick comebacks. Oppenheimer's India Fund, for example, managed by Punita Kumar-Sinha, has averaged a gain of 37.8 percent, annualized, over the last three years. It had a surge of 139.3 percent in 2003 and a decline of 20.8 percent in 2001. 
 Returns of Oppenheimer's Asia Tigers fund, also managed by Ms. Kumar-Sinha, have not been quite as volatile. The fund, which is more diversified, has returned 15.9 percent, on average, over the last three years. Last year, when the fund was up 10.5 percent, it had about 30 percent of its holdings in South Korea, 10 percent in India and 2.4 percent in China. ''In India last year we were overweighted in construction, engineering and capital goods,'' she said, adding that the company had positions in Bharat Heavy Electricals and in ABB India, both power-equipment manufacturers. 
 ''In China we liked the consumer sector,'' she said, with holdings in People's Food, largely a pork processing company, and the Want Want Group, a food company whose main product is rice crackers.
 SOME analysts are bullish on India. Nandita Parker, who runs the Karma Fund, a small hedge fund that invests in Indian stocks and jumped 37 percent last year, said that the economy was expected to sustain economic growth of 6 to 8 percent a year over the next several years, slower than the 8.25 percent growth of last year. But Mr. Rees-Mogg has pulled back his fund's holdings in India, he said, because he thought valuations there were too high. 
 And some analysts say that while the Russian market is now relatively inexpensive, the short-term outlook for stocks is very uncertain, because of the battle between Vladimir V. Putin, the Russian president, and Yukos, the nation's largest oil company. Yukos is seeking bankruptcy protection in federal court in Houston, while the Russian government is trying to liquidate it. 
 Indeed, the volatility of emerging markets can sometimes make investors' stomachs churn. That is why diversification in these markets may be a smart move. When a market plummets, ''if it is 10 percent of your portfolio, it is annoying; if it is 100 percent, well . . .'' Mr. Rees-Mogg said.

HEADLINE: A Bookkeeping Error Adds To Heating Bills Statewide

BYLINE: By IAN URBINA

 BODY:
While it has been a relatively mild winter, it may not feel that way for people who heat their homes with natural gas. Heating bills in New York State have increased by more than 20 percent since last winter as the price for natural gas has gone through the roof. But for some people the spike is even bigger because they are still feeling the effects of a bookkeeping error that sent the gas market haywire in November.
 It all started around noon on Nov. 24 when a federal agency known as the Energy Information Administration issued its weekly report on natural gas inventories. The report indicated erroneously that there would be one-third as much gas put into storage that week as the industry expected, sending energy traders on a buying frenzy. 
 ''It was a complete panic,'' said Saul Horowitz, chief executive officer of Econnergy, a company based in Spring Valley, about 20 miles north of Manhattan. ''The price for natural gas went from $6.30 per thousand cubic feet of natural gas to $8.05 in less than hour.'' The error led Econnergy to pay more than $6 million extra for its gas, a charge that is being passed to its 160,000 customers.
 Part of the mistake was caused by Dominion Transmission Inc., an interstate gas transmission company based in Clarksburg, W.Va., which submitted incorrect numbers to federal regulators. But even though company officials notified federal regulators of the mistake later the same day, the Energy Information Administration, an agency within the Department of Energy, did not publicly correct the mistake until it printed its next report, a week later.
 Last May, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission adopted new rules against market manipulation that required utilities to give back profits earned as a result of data that was intentionally misconstrued. But against the arguments of consumer advocacy groups, federal regulators decided not to require utilities to return profits based on data that was unintentionally misconstrued.
 On Friday, Senator Charles E. Schumer sent a letter to the energy administration requesting an exact figure on how much New York customers paid for gas bought at the price that had been inflated in error. A spokesman for Mr. Schumer said that federal officials had estimated that the mistake inflated consumer fuel costs nationwide by $200 million to $1 billion.
 David C. Flanagan, a spokesman for the New York State Public Service Commission, which regulates utilities in the state, said that the commission had asked the Energy Information Administration to begin publishing its reports daily rather than weekly so that problems could be caught sooner.
 Econnergy and other small energy providers in the state were hit hardest by the mistake because they depend more on short-term markets for buying gas. 
 Larger utilities like Consolidated Edison and KeySpan Energy Corporation are less vulnerable to short-term markets because they usually buy much more gas in advance.
 ''The impact we felt was ameliorated by the fact that we keep a diverse portfolio of short- and long-term contracts,'' said Chris Olert, a spokesman for Consolidated Edison, which has about 1.1 million gas customers. An average Con Ed residential gas customer, who paid about $888 for home heating fuel from November 2003 through January 2004, paid about $1,040 for the same period ending last month, he said. For competitive reasons, Mr. Olert said he could not disclose how much the utility bought from short-term markets or how much of this winter's price increase was a result of the energy administration's error.
 The manager of regulatory affairs for KeySpan, Joan Graves, said that its 1.5 million gas customers in the New York City region would probably face an 11 percent increase in their bills this winter from last. Although she could not estimate how much the utility had been affected by the recent error, she said that the bigger variable had been the nationwide increase in natural gas prices.
 The price of natural gas has increased by more than 30 percent nationwide in the last year.
 ''New York customers are simply too vulnerable to the short-term fluctuations in energy spot markets,'' said Gerald A. Norlander, executive director of the Public Utility Law Project in Albany. ''The state needs to catch up with the national trend in which utilities are becoming less dependent on short-term buying.'' 
 In an Oct. 7 petition to the Public Service Commission, Con Ed requested that state regulators push all utilities to buy more of their gas from longer-term markets in an effort to stabilize prices. The commission denied the petition in December.
 ''We still don't have a figure on how many people in New York were affected by this mistake,'' said John B. Howard, chief of staff for State Assemblyman Paul D. Tonko, chairman of the Assembly's Energy Committee. ''But I think it's pretty clear that we need more regulations on how these utilities operate.''

HEADLINE: Paying Homage to Hollywood's High Holy Days

BYLINE: By SALLY HORCHOW

 BODY:

Why Go Now
 The historian Carey McWilliams once said that being in Los Angeles was like having a ''ringside seat at the circus.'' Never is that truer than during the entertainment industry's high holy days -- the awards season -- which culminate in the 77th annual Academy Awards at the Kodak Theater on Feb. 27. 
 Between the frenzy of award-related parties, the rush of the ''-ists'' (stylists, publicists, hair and makeup artists) to properly adorn their clients, and the flash of celebrities at every turn, it's difficult not to get caught up in the ''Hooray for Hollywood''-soundtracked excitement -- even if a ticket, guest-list inclusion or Oscar nomination evades you.

Where to Stay
 Although Los Angeles has a premium selection of hotels, the more centrally located luxury fare offer the best vantage points. The elegant 85-room 2 Four Seasons Hotel Los Angeles at Beverly Hills, 300 South Doheny Drive, (310) 273-2222; www.fourseasons.com/losangeles, is the entertainment industry's year-round home away from home. Leading up to the Oscars, the hotel celebrates its Hollywood family with specialty cocktails, a three-week exhibition of the pastry chef's confections inspired by each nominee for best picture and a viewing party for the few guests who don't attend the ceremony. The hotel's famously grand floral arrangements seem much more lush, and the pool and lobby bar seem much more glamorous when you spot Liam Neeson, Cate Blanchett or Morgan Freeman around them. Double rooms start at $375. 
 Down the street, The Peninsula Beverly Hills Hotel, 9882 South Santa Monica Boulevard, (310) 551-2888, www.peninsula.com, takes a more subtle approach to its Oscar revelry. As a result, its guests are often heads of state, privacy-seeking stars and, most notably, Miramax Films executives (the Weinstein brothers hold court there). The French country estate decor and over-the-top service, with amenities like free monogrammed pillowcases (upon request) and 24-hour check-in and check-out, add to the hotel's refined ambience, though the lobby still gets its share of rushed stylists and harried assistants during Oscar week. On Oscar Sunday, when an onslaught of limousines surrounds the hotel, the crisply uniformed valets coordinate the departures with aplomb, calling up to the room as a guest's car enters the cobblestone driveway. The subsequent lobby walk is the first red-carpet parade of the day and worth the price of admission, which is $425 to $575 for a double and a place on the general manager's tightly controlled reservation list. 
 In 1929, when the first Academy Awards were given out at the Hollywood Roosevelt Hotel, the legendary Chateau Marmont, 8221 Sunset Boulevard, (323) 656-1010, www.chateaumarmont.com, was being built a few miles west. Thanks to the high profile of its current owner, Andre Balazs, and a smartly done renovation in the 1990's, the European-style Chateau remains the hotel of choice for cosmopolitan creative types. Originally a luxury apartment complex, most of the rooms have kitchenettes. But the nightly goings-on in the salon-like lobby -- more living room than entrance hall -- are the reason to stay there. Place your entourage in one of the period seating vignettes and watch Javier Bardem, Leonardo DiCaprio and Pamela Anderson inhale the same smoke-filled air. Doubles start at $315. Belushi's infamous bungalow: $1,500.

Where to Eat
 The Ivy, 113 North Robertson Boulevard, (310) 274-8303, is on one of the most popular shopping streets in town, making it an ideal spot for lunch, though securing a table on the street-front patio is like getting a ticket to the Oscar ceremony itself. The never-changing menu of crab cakes, chopped salads and grilled items takes a back seat to the rubbernecking to see celebrities, or the ducking from paparazzi by the stars. Open daily for lunch and dinner.
 Perhaps a slightly easier reservation, but just as much a power lunch or dinner spot, the Polo Lounge at the Beverly Hills Hotel, 9641 Sunset Boulevard, (310) 887-2777, aka the Pink Palace, with its banana-leaf wallpaper and standard-playing pianist, packs an old-school Hollywood punch but is just as popular with the young set. Order the famous McCarthy salad ($20) and look out for regulars like Warren and Annette.
 Across town, there is never a dull moment at Mauro's Cafe in the Fred Segal Center, 8100 Melrose Avenue, (323) 653-2874, where a selection of delicious pastas is shunned by the carb-free likes of Paris Hilton and Jennifer Garner for the spinach salad or vegetable sautes. Others embrace the traditional Italian fare, tiramisu and all, before a calorie-burning session in the adjoining trendy Ron Herman boutiques.
 If you want to follow the ''it'' crowd to dinner, head to Koi, 730 North La Cienega Boulevard, (310) 659-9449, for sushi and sake and sightings. It's open nightly, except on Oscar Sunday, when it's being rented for a top-secret Oscar party.

What to Do During the Day
 On any other visit, a jaunt to the surf breaks of Malibu or taking in a performance at Frank Gehry's Disney Concert Hall would be compulsory. This time, Oscar prep time is essential. Nominees, presenters and their stylists spend the week attending private in-suite shopping sprees at hotels. But apparel worthy of the red carpet is readily available around town for everyone else.
 The second-floor couture department at Barneys New York, 9570 Wilshire Boulevard, (310) 276-4400, is the best place to start. Unless it's the afternoon before the Oscar ceremony, when most stars attend the Independent Spirit Awards in Santa Monica, you're bound to spot a few descending the grand staircase. The dizzying shoe department has the best collection of Manolo Blahnik, Marc Jacobs and Prada around. 
 For gowns, resist the temptation to hit the Rodeo Drive stores -- you can see those anywhere -- and go to Decades, upstairs at 8214 1/2 Melrose Avenue, (323) 655-0223, a vintage couture boutique where the owner, Cameron Silver, expertly edits classic eveningwear from the 1920's to the 1970's. To secure a fitting of the apple-green Galanos chiffon gown from the 1970's ($3,600) or the Nina Ricci strapless floral gown from the same era ($4,200) that have been on display, visit the salon Monday through Saturday from 11:30 a.m. to 6 p.m. 
 The reigning queen of a new generation of jewelry designers is Erica Courtney, 7465 Beverly Boulevard, (323) 938-2850, www.ericacourtney.com, who has taken her rightful place on the red carpet next to Harry Winston and Neil Lane. On view at her boutique are platinum, diamond and colored-stone baubles (for $9,000 to $120,000) that you just might see at the Awards show. 
 After shopping, it's time to get ready for your close-up -- an industry in its own right, with every Beverly Hills spa trying to entice nominees with new treatments containing diamonds, caviar or other potentially luck-enhancing ingredients. But dedicated clients of the Face Place, 8701 Santa Monica Boulevard, (310) 855-1150, which include Sofia Coppola, Michelle Pfeiffer and Johnny Depp, prefer this West Hollywood hideaway's year-round anti-aging approach: a no-nonsense facial using galvanic current. 
 The 2 Spa at the Four Seasons Hotel Los Angeles at Beverly Hills, 300 South Doheny Drive, (310) 273-2222, is the only place in town to get Sun FX ($85), a new, odor-free Australian airbrush tanning treatment that will cast a streak-free bronze. Exfoliate with a chamomile body scrub ($85) first, and the tan will last through the week. 
 Christophe and Frederic Fekkai may be too busy to create your updo on Oscar weekend, but who goes to a salon anymore, anyway? Fred Segal Mobile, from Fred Segal Beauty at 420 Broadway in Santa Monica, (310) 451-3808 or on the Web at www.fredsegalbeauty.com, will bring all of its services -- from a basic blow dry ($125) to a make-up application ($125) to a wardrobe styling ($175 an hour) -- right to your hotel room. 
 While you're at it, have a customized, delivered workout from Absolution, 8535 Santa Monica Boulevard, (310) 657-7878; www.absolution-la.com, a fitness center in West Hollywood that dispatches instructors in myriad practices, including Pilates, yoga, rock climbing -- even strip tease.

What to Do at Night
 ArcLight, 6360 West Sunset Boulevard, Hollywood, (323) 464-4226 or at www.arclightcinemas.com, offers an only-in-Hollywood movie experience, and for a city of film buffs, every detail -- including reserved seating, double-wide cinema chairs, THX systems and real butter for popcorn -- counts. Look for ''21+'' shows, when you can watch nominated films while sipping a martini or margarita from the lobby bar. 
 If yours was not one of the 300 names drawn on Oct. 1 for a bleacher seat at the Kodak, or you aren't Joan Rivers, you should plan on screening the red carpet arrivals on your television of choice. But if you later head to the Vanity Fair party at Mortons Restaurant, 8764 Melrose Avenue, (310) 276-5205, you can stand behind velvet ropes across Robertson Boulevard and watch the parade of stars. Who knows? You might just be discovered.

Your First Time or 10th
 Started in 1934 when a contingent of farmers displayed their produce on their truck's tailgates, the charming Farmers Market at 6333 West Third Street at Fairfax Avenue, (323) 933-9211, www.farmersmarketla.com, now has more than 70 shops and stalls (selling everything from gumbo to goat cheese). This place is the real deal: a unique melting pot of octogenarians, Japanese tourists, businessmen on lunch and yes, celebrities, gathered daily for the varied food choices and a respite from the city's other star attractions. 

How to Get Around
 Don't even think of public transportation: in Los Angeles, it's all about your car. To fit right in, forgo the Kia and call Beverly Hills Rent-a-Car, (800) 479-5996 or at www.bhrentacar.com. They will meet you at the airport or a hotel with one of a fleet of luxury cars, which includes a Hummer H2 ($349 a day), a new Rolls-Royce Phantom ($2,995 a day), and, for Leo-lovers, an economical, but trendy, Honda hybrid ($89 a day).

HEADLINE: Older Hands Find Place in a New Course

BYLINE: By Nicholas Confessore. 
This column about the local economy appears every other week. E-mail address: homefront@nytimes.com

 BODY:
FOR the last few years, Jack McGourty, an associate dean at Columbia University's engineering school, has been dispatching his department's first-year students into the neighborhoods of Upper Manhattan. There, they have applied the same talents that got them into one of the country's most selective colleges to helping those who have not had quite so many opportunities.But this year, Columbia's undergraduates will be joined by a few older faces: participants in a new program that gives out-of-work New Yorkers a chance to take classes at an Ivy League university, then puts them to work on service projects that use what they have learned.
 ''We like to say it's the community helping the community,'' says Dr. McGourty. 
 The new initiative, known as the Gateway Workforce Development Program, began last fall. Once a week, 20 New Yorkers -- selected by Managed Work Services, a Bronx-based employment services organization and Columbia's partner in the effort -- come to classes at the computer lab at the Fu Foundation School of Engineering and Applied Sciences. They learn how to operate Web design software, but just as important, they work on group projects and attend lectures on skills that can be harder to learn, like communicating with colleagues and managing team members who do not get along. 
 As the semester rolls on, the participants will begin designing a Web site for the program's client, Morningside Gardens, a middle-income housing development. (Last semester's participants did the same for the West Side Inter-Agency Council for the Aging.) Some students have had software training, Dr. McGourty said, but others ''have never even turned on a computer.''
 By combining the traditional ''service learning'' approach with training in job skills, Columbia's program aims to overcome a problem associated with traditional work programs: they cannot always provide on-the-job experience. 
 ''This program is more giving you experience in the real world,'' said one participant, Venus Lee, a Brooklyn woman in her late 50's who lost her job with I.B.M. a decade ago and has struggled to find full-time work while looking after her brother, who has required constant care since he was injured in a robbery in 1991. 
 ''The client gets a full-functioning Web site that fulfills their needs,'' Dr. McGourty said. ''And the students are put in a real working condition.''
 He continued: ''They have to work together and collaborate with both each other and the client. They have to manage their time and manage all the tasks involved in completing the product.''
 Dr. McGourty said he and his colleagues also believed that other programs did not teach the kind of life skills that many chronically unemployed people lack. ''What makes this different from other work programs,'' said Mary Sprague, the director of Managed Work Services, is its ''richness.'' ''So many of the training programs are very skill-oriented,'' she said. '''I'll teach you to be a dental assistant or a commercial driver.' This is much more holistic.''
 Cynthia Connor is an unemployed 32-year-old from Brooklyn whose last job was with the city's Parks Department. She was taking a computer course when she heard about the Gateway program, which she said she hoped would help her deal with a problem more perplexing than navigating menu screens or sorting Excel spreadsheets. 
 ''I don't get along well with other people,'' she said. ''And I can't get ahead like that. Here, I'm in an environment where I can learn to work with people.''
 Though the program's record on moving participants into full-time work is mixed -- some of last semester's eight students remain unemployed, others are working, and a few are now taking classes elsewhere with an eye toward finding a job down the line -- Dr. McGourty and Ms. Sprague said they believed that the program's real value is sometimes more elusive.
 ''This is really about self-esteem,'' Ms. Sprague said, citing the example of a student from last semester who, before joining the program, could not even bring himself to fill out college applications and now plans to study engineering. Frank Silverberg of Manhattan graduated from New York University in 1970 and spent 20 years in the textile industry, then retrained to be a programmer and got a job as one -- only to be laid off when his bosses decided they wanted someone with different expertise. He came to Columbia, he said, to ''increase my skills and get my own business started.'' He said he also likes ''the prestige of attending classes at an Ivy League school.''
